73     //--------------------------------------------------------------
74     // Metadata:
75     //   HeapBlock.id :: Seg (stored as heap shadowchunk; always non-zero)
76     //   MemLoc.aseg  :: Seg (implicitly stored)
77     //   MemLoc.vseg  :: Seg (explicitly stored as the shadow memory)
78     //   RegLoc.vseg  :: Seg (explicitly stored as shadow registers)
79     //
80     // A Seg is made when new memory is created, eg. with malloc() or mmap().
81     // There are two other Segs:
82     //  - NONPTR:  for something that's definitely not a pointer
83     //  - UNKNOWN: for something that could be a pointer
84     //  - BOTTOM:  used with pointer differences (see below)
85     //
86     // MemLoc.vseg is done at word granularity.  If a pointer is written
87     // to memory misaligned, the information about it will be lost -- it's
88     // treated as two sub-word writes to two adjacent words.  This avoids
89     // certain nasty cases that could arise if we tried to track unaligned
90     // pointers.  Fortunately, misalignment is rare so we don't lose much
91     // information this way.
92     //
93     // MemLoc.aseg is done at byte granularity, and *implicitly* -- ie. not
94     // directly accessible like MemLoc.vseg, but only by searching through all
95     // the segments.  Fortunately, it's mostly checked at LOADs/STOREs;  at that
96     // point we have a pointer p to the MemLoc m as the other arg of the
97     // LOAD/STORE, so we can check to see if the p.vseg's range includes m.  If
98     // not, it's an error and we have to search through all segments to find out
99     // what m.aseg really is.  That's still pretty fast though, thanks to the
100     // interval skip-list used.  With syscalls we must also do the skip-list
101     // search, but only on the first and last bytes touched.
102     //--------------------------------------------------------------
103     
104     //--------------------------------------------------------------
105     // Assumptions, etc:
106     // - see comment at top of SK_(instrument)() for how sub-word ops are
107     //   handled.
108     //
109     // - ioctl(), socketcall() (and ipc() will be) assumed to return non-pointers
110     //
111     // - FPU_W is assumed to never write pointers.
112     //
113     // - Assuming none of the post_mem_writes create segments worth tracking.
114     //
115     // - Treating mmap'd segments (all! including code) like heap segments.  But
116     //   their ranges can change, new ones can be created by unmapping parts of
117     //   old segments, etc.  But this nasty behaviour seems to never happen -- 
118     //   there are assertions checking it.
119     //--------------------------------------------------------------
120     
121     //--------------------------------------------------------------
122     // What I am checking:
123     // - Type errors:
124     //    * ADD, OR, LEA2: error if two pointer inputs.
125     //    * ADC, SBB: error if one or two pointer inputs.
126     //    * AND, OR: error if two unequal pointer inputs.
127     //    * NEG: error if pointer input.
128     //    * {,i}mul_32_64 if either input is a pointer.
129     //    * shldl/shrdl, bsf/bsr if any inputs are pointers.
130     //
131     // - LOAD, STORE:
132     //    * ptr.vseg must match ptee.aseg.
133     //    * ptee.aseg must not be a freed segment.
134     //
135     // - syscalls: for those accessing memory, look at first and last bytes:
136     //    * check first.aseg == last.aseg
137     //    * check first.aseg and last.aseg are not freed segments.
138     //
139     // What I am not checking, that I expected to when I started:
140     // - AND, XOR: allowing two pointers to be used if both from the same segment,
141     //   because "xor %r,%r" is commonly used to zero %r, and "test %r,%r"
142     //   (which is translated with an AND) is common too.
143     //
144     // - div_64_32/idiv_64_32 can take pointer inputs for the dividend;
145     //   division doesn't make sense, but modulo does, and they're done with the
146     //   same instruction.  (Could try to be super-clever and watch the outputs
147     //   to see if the quotient is used, but not worth it.)
148     //
149     // - mul_64_32/imul_64_32 can take pointers inputs for one arg or the
150     //   other, but not both.  This is because some programs (eg. Mozilla
151     //   Firebird) multiply pointers in hash routines.
152     //
153     // - NEG: can take a pointer.  It happens in glibc in a few places.  I've
154     //   seen the code, didn't understand it, but it's done deliberately.
155     //
156     // What I am not checking/doing, but could, but it would require more
157     // instrumentation and/or slow things down a bit:
158     // - SUB: when differencing two pointers, result is BOTTOM, ie. "don't
159     //   check".  Could link segments instead, slower but a bit more accurate.
160     //   Also use BOTTOM when doing (ptr - unknown), which could be a pointer
161     //   difference with a stack/static pointer.
162     //
163     // - PUTF: input should be non-pointer
164     //
165     // - arithmetic error messages: eg. for adding two pointers, just giving the
166     //   segments, not the actual pointers.
167     //
168     // What I am not checking, and would be difficult:
169     // - mmap(...MAP_FIXED...) is not handled specially.  It might be used in
170     //   ways that fool Ptrcheck into giving false positives.
171     //
172     // - syscalls: for those accessing memory, not checking that the asegs of the
173     //   accessed words match the vseg of the accessing pointer, because the
174     //   vseg is not easily accessible at the required time (would required
175     //   knowing for every syscall which register each arg came in, and looking
176     //   there).
177     //
178     // What I am not checking, and would be difficult, but doesn't matter:
179     // - free(p): similar to syscalls, not checking that the p.vseg matches the
180     //   aseg of the first byte in the block.  However, Memcheck does an
181     //   equivalent "bad free" check using shadow_chunks;  indeed, Ptrcheck could
182     //   do the same check, but there's no point duplicating functionality.  So
183     //   no loss, really.
184     //
185     // Other:
186     // - not doing anything with mprotect();  probably not worth the effort.
187     //--------------------------------------------------------------
188     
189     //--------------------------------------------------------------
190     // Todo:
191     // - Segments for stack frames.  Would detect (some, large) stack
192     //   over/under-runs, dangling pointers.
193     //
194     // - Segments for static data.  Would detect over/under-runs.  Requires
195     //   reading debug info.
196     //--------------------------------------------------------------
197     
198     //--------------------------------------------------------------

200     //                                                 twolf   konq    date sz

204     // 4. (made check_load, check_store4 regparm(0))          (27.9s) (11.0)
205     // 5. um, not sure                                 5.3s    27.3s   10.6

207     // 6. after big changes, corrections              11.2s    32.8s   14.0
208     // 7. removed link-segment chasing in check/L/S    8.9s    30.8s   14.0
209     // 8. avoiding do_lea1 if k is a nonptr            8.0s    28.0s   12.9
210     //--------------------------------------------------------------

249     /* Set to 1 to do sanity checks on Seg values in many places, which
250        checks if bogus Segs are in circulation.  Quite expensive from a
251        performance point of view. */
252     #define SC_SEGS 0
253     
254     static ULong stats__client_mallocs = 0;
255     static ULong stats__client_frees   = 0;
256     static ULong stats__segs_allocd    = 0;
257     static ULong stats__segs_recycled  = 0;

260     //////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
261     //                                                          //
262     // Segments low level storage                               //
263     //                                                          //
264     //////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
265     
266     // NONPTR, UNKNOWN, BOTTOM defined in h_main.h since 
267     // pc_common.c needs to see them, for error processing
268     
269     // we only start recycling segs when this many exist
270     #define N_FREED_SEGS (1 * 1000 * 1000)
271     
272     struct _Seg {
273        Addr  addr;
274        SizeT szB; /* may be zero */
275        ExeContext* ec;  /* where malloc'd or freed */
276        /* When 1, indicates block is in use.  Otherwise, used to form a
277           linked list of freed blocks, running from oldest freed block to
278           the most recently freed block. */
279        struct _Seg* nextfree;
280     };
281     
282     // Determines if 'a' is before, within, or after seg's range.  Sets 'cmp' to
283     // -1/0/1 accordingly.  Sets 'n' to the number of bytes before/within/after.
284     void Seg__cmp(Seg* seg, Addr a, Int* cmp, UWord* n)
285     {
286        if (a < seg->addr) {
287           *cmp = -1;
288           *n   = seg->addr - a;
289        } else if (a < seg->addr + seg->szB && seg->szB > 0) {
290           *cmp = 0;
291           *n = a - seg->addr;
292        } else {
293           *cmp = 1;
294           *n = a - (seg->addr + seg->szB);
295        }
296     }
297     
298     inline Bool Seg__is_freed(Seg* seg)
299     {
300        if (!is_known_segment(seg))
301           return False;
302        else
303           return seg->nextfree != (Seg*)1;
304     }
305     
306     ExeContext* Seg__where(Seg* seg)
307     {
308        tl_assert(is_known_segment(seg));
309        return seg->ec;
310     }
311     
312     SizeT Seg__size(Seg* seg)
313     {
314        tl_assert(is_known_segment(seg));
315        return seg->szB;
316     }
317     
318     Addr Seg__addr(Seg* seg)
319     {
320        tl_assert(is_known_segment(seg));
321        return seg->addr;
322     }

325     #define N_SEGS_PER_GROUP 10000
326     
327     typedef
328        struct _SegGroup {
329           struct _SegGroup* admin;
330           UWord nextfree; /* 0 .. N_SEGS_PER_GROUP */
331           Seg segs[N_SEGS_PER_GROUP];
332        }
333        SegGroup;
334     
335     static SegGroup* group_list = NULL;
336     static UWord     nFreeSegs = 0;
337     static Seg*      freesegs_youngest = NULL;
338     static Seg*      freesegs_oldest = NULL;
339     
340     
341     static SegGroup* new_SegGroup ( void ) {
342        SegGroup* g = VG_(malloc)("pc.h_main.nTG.1", sizeof(SegGroup));
343        VG_(memset)(g, 0, sizeof(*g));
344        return g;
345     }
346     
347     /* Get a completely new Seg */
348     static Seg* new_Seg ( void )
349     {
350        Seg*      teg;
351        SegGroup* g;
352        if (group_list == NULL) {
353           g = new_SegGroup();
354           g->admin = NULL;
355           group_list = g;
356        }
357        tl_assert(group_list->nextfree <= N_SEGS_PER_GROUP);
358        if (group_list->nextfree == N_SEGS_PER_GROUP) {
359           g = new_SegGroup();
360           g->admin = group_list;
361           group_list = g;
362        }
363        tl_assert(group_list->nextfree < N_SEGS_PER_GROUP);
364        teg = &group_list->segs[ group_list->nextfree ];
365        group_list->nextfree++;
366        stats__segs_allocd++;
367        return teg;
368     }
369     
370     static Seg* get_Seg_for_malloc ( void )
371     {
372        Seg* seg;
373        if (nFreeSegs < N_FREED_SEGS) {
374           seg = new_Seg();
375           seg->nextfree = (Seg*)1;
376           return seg;
377        }
378        /* else recycle the oldest Seg in the free list */
379        tl_assert(freesegs_youngest);
380        tl_assert(freesegs_oldest);
381        tl_assert(freesegs_youngest != freesegs_oldest);
382        seg = freesegs_oldest;
383        freesegs_oldest = seg->nextfree;
384        nFreeSegs--;
385        seg->nextfree = (Seg*)1;
386        stats__segs_recycled++;
387        return seg;
388     }
389     
390     static void set_Seg_freed ( Seg* seg )
391     {
392        tl_assert(seg);
393        tl_assert(!Seg__is_freed(seg));
394        if (nFreeSegs == 0) {
395           tl_assert(freesegs_oldest == NULL);
396           tl_assert(freesegs_youngest == NULL);
397           seg->nextfree = NULL;
398           freesegs_youngest = seg;
399           freesegs_oldest = seg;
400           nFreeSegs++;
401        } else {
402           tl_assert(freesegs_youngest);
403           tl_assert(freesegs_oldest);
404           if (nFreeSegs == 1) {
405              tl_assert(freesegs_youngest == freesegs_oldest);
406           } else {
407              tl_assert(freesegs_youngest != freesegs_oldest);
408           }
409           tl_assert(freesegs_youngest->nextfree == NULL);
410           tl_assert(seg != freesegs_youngest && seg != freesegs_oldest);
411           seg->nextfree = NULL;
412           freesegs_youngest->nextfree = seg;
413           freesegs_youngest = seg;
414           nFreeSegs++;
415        }
416     }
417     
418     static WordFM* addr_to_seg_map = NULL; /* GuestAddr -> Seg* */
419     
420     static void addr_to_seg_map_ENSURE_INIT ( void )
421     {
422        if (UNLIKELY(addr_to_seg_map == NULL)) {
423           addr_to_seg_map = VG_(newFM)( VG_(malloc), "pc.h_main.attmEI.1",
424                                         VG_(free), NULL/*unboxedcmp*/ );
425        }
426     }
427     
428     static Seg* find_Seg_by_addr ( Addr ga )
429     {
430        UWord keyW, valW;
431        addr_to_seg_map_ENSURE_INIT();
432        if (VG_(lookupFM)( addr_to_seg_map, &keyW, &valW, (UWord)ga )) {
433           tl_assert(keyW == ga);
434           return (Seg*)valW;
435        } else {
436           return NULL;
437        }
438     }
439     
440     static void bind_addr_to_Seg ( Addr ga, Seg* seg )
441     {
442        Bool b;
443        addr_to_seg_map_ENSURE_INIT();
444        b = VG_(addToFM)( addr_to_seg_map, (UWord)ga, (UWord)seg );
445        tl_assert(!b); /* else ga is already bound */
446     }
447     
448     static void unbind_addr_from_Seg ( Addr ga )
449     {
450        Bool b;
451        UWord keyW, valW;
452        addr_to_seg_map_ENSURE_INIT();
453        b = VG_(delFromFM)( addr_to_seg_map, &keyW, &valW, (UWord)ga );
454        tl_assert(b); /* else ga was not already bound */
455        tl_assert(keyW == ga);
456        tl_assert(valW != 0);
457     }

464     // So that post_reg_write_clientcall knows the segment just allocated.
465     static Seg* last_seg_added = NULL;
466     
467     // Returns the added heap segment
468     static Seg* add_new_segment ( ThreadId tid, Addr p, SizeT size )
469     {
470        Seg* seg = get_Seg_for_malloc();
471        tl_assert(seg != (Seg*)1); /* since we're using 1 as a special value */
472        seg->addr = p;
473        seg->szB  = size;
474        seg->ec   = VG_(record_ExeContext)( tid, 0/*first_ip_delta*/ );
475        tl_assert(!Seg__is_freed(seg));
476     
477        bind_addr_to_Seg(p, seg);
478     
479        last_seg_added = seg;
480     
481        return seg;
482     }
483     
484     // Forward declarations
485     static void copy_mem( Addr from, Addr to, SizeT len );
486     static void set_mem_unknown ( Addr a, SizeT len );
487     
488     static inline VG_REGPARM(1) Seg* nonptr_or_unknown(UWord x); /*fwds*/
489     
490     static
491     void* alloc_and_new_mem_heap ( ThreadId tid,
492                                    SizeT size, SizeT alignment, Bool is_zeroed )
493     {
494        Addr p;
495     
496        if ( ((SSizeT)size) < 0) return NULL;
497     
498        p = (Addr)VG_(cli_malloc)(alignment, size);
499        if (is_zeroed) VG_(memset)((void*)p, 0, size);
500     
501        set_mem_unknown( p, size );
502        add_new_segment( tid, p, size );
503     
504        stats__client_mallocs++;
505        return (void*)p;
506     }
507     
508     static void die_and_free_mem_heap ( ThreadId tid, Seg* seg )
509     {
510        // Empty and free the actual block
511        tl_assert(!Seg__is_freed(seg));
512        set_mem_unknown( seg->addr, seg->szB );
513     
514        VG_(cli_free)( (void*)seg->addr );
515     
516        // Remember where freed
517        seg->ec = VG_(record_ExeContext)( tid, 0/*first_ip_delta*/ );
518     
519        set_Seg_freed(seg);
520        unbind_addr_from_Seg( seg->addr );
521     
522        stats__client_frees++;
523     }
524     
525     static void handle_free_heap( ThreadId tid, void* p )
526     {
527        Seg* seg = find_Seg_by_addr( (Addr)p );
528        if (!seg) {
529           /* freeing a block that wasn't malloc'd.  Ignore. */
530           return;
531        }
532        die_and_free_mem_heap( tid, seg );
533     }

536     /*------------------------------------------------------------*/
537     /*--- Shadow memory                                        ---*/
538     /*------------------------------------------------------------*/
539     
540     /* Shadow memory holds one Seg for each naturally aligned (guest)
541        word.  For a 32 bit target (assuming host word size == guest word
542        size) that means one Seg per 4 bytes, and each Seg occupies 4
543        bytes.  For a 64 bit target that means one Seg per 8 bytes, and
544        each Seg occupies 8 bytes.  Hence in each case the overall space
545        overhead for shadow memory is 1:1.
546     
547        This does however make it a bit tricky to size SecMap.vseg[], simce
548        it needs to hold 16384 entries for 32 bit targets but only 8192
549        entries for 64 bit targets. */
550     
551     #if 0
552     __attribute__((unused))
553     static void pp_curr_ExeContext(void)
554     {
555        VG_(pp_ExeContext)(
556           VG_(get_ExeContext)(
557              VG_(get_current_or_recent_tid)() ) );
558        VG_(message)(Vg_UserMsg, "");
559     }
560     #endif
561     
562     #if defined(VGA_x86) || defined(VGA_ppc32) || defined(VGA_arm)
563     #  define SHMEM_SECMAP_MASK         0xFFFC
564     #  define SHMEM_SECMAP_SHIFT        2
565     #  define SHMEM_IS_WORD_ALIGNED(_a) VG_IS_4_ALIGNED(_a)
566     #  define SEC_MAP_WORDS             (0x10000UL / 4UL) /* 16k */
567     #elif defined(VGA_amd64) || defined(VGA_ppc64) || defined(VGA_s390x)
568     #  define SHMEM_SECMAP_MASK         0xFFF8
569     #  define SHMEM_SECMAP_SHIFT        3
570     #  define SHMEM_IS_WORD_ALIGNED(_a) VG_IS_8_ALIGNED(_a)
571     #  define SEC_MAP_WORDS             (0x10000UL / 8UL) /* 8k */
572     #else
573     #  error "Unknown arch"
574     #endif
575     
576     typedef
577        struct {
578           Seg* vseg[SEC_MAP_WORDS];
579        }
580        SecMap;
581     
582     static SecMap  distinguished_secondary_map;
583     
584     /* An entry in the primary map.  base must be a 64k-aligned value, and
585        sm points at the relevant secondary map.  The secondary may be
586        either a real secondary, or the distinguished secondary.  DO NOT
587        CHANGE THIS LAYOUT: the first word has to be the key for OSet fast
588        lookups.
589     */
590     typedef
591        struct {
592           Addr    base;
593           SecMap* sm;
594        }
595        PriMapEnt;
596     
597     /* Primary map is an OSet of PriMapEnt (primap_L2), "fronted" by a
598        cache (primap_L1). */
599     
600     /* Tunable parameter: How big is the L1 queue? */
601     #define N_PRIMAP_L1 24
602     
603     /* Tunable parameter: How far along the L1 queue to insert
604        entries resulting from L2 lookups? */
605     #define PRIMAP_L1_INSERT_IX 12
606     
607     static struct {
608               Addr       base; // must be 64k aligned
609               PriMapEnt* ent; // pointer to the matching primap_L2 node
610            }
611            primap_L1[N_PRIMAP_L1];
612     
613     static OSet* primap_L2 = NULL;
614     
615     
616     /* # searches initiated in auxmap_L1, and # base cmps required */
617     static ULong n_primap_L1_searches  = 0;
618     static ULong n_primap_L1_cmps      = 0;
619     /* # of searches that missed in auxmap_L1 and therefore had to
620        be handed to auxmap_L2. And the number of nodes inserted. */
621     static ULong n_primap_L2_searches  = 0;
622     static ULong n_primap_L2_nodes     = 0;
623     
624     
625     static void init_shadow_memory ( void )
626     {
627        Int i;
628     
629        for (i = 0; i < SEC_MAP_WORDS; i++)
630           distinguished_secondary_map.vseg[i] = NONPTR;
631     
632        for (i = 0; i < N_PRIMAP_L1; i++) {
633           primap_L1[i].base = 1; /* not 64k aligned, so doesn't match any
634                                     request ==> slot is empty */
635           primap_L1[i].ent  = NULL;
636        }
637     
638        tl_assert(0 == offsetof(PriMapEnt,base));
639        tl_assert(sizeof(Addr) == sizeof(void*));
640        primap_L2 = VG_(OSetGen_Create)( /*keyOff*/  offsetof(PriMapEnt,base),
641                                         /*fastCmp*/ NULL,
642                                         VG_(malloc), "pc.h_main.ism.1",
643                                         VG_(free) );
644        tl_assert(primap_L2);
645     }
646     
647     static void insert_into_primap_L1_at ( Word rank, PriMapEnt* ent )
648     {
649        Word i;
650        tl_assert(ent);
651        tl_assert(rank >= 0 && rank < N_PRIMAP_L1);
652        for (i = N_PRIMAP_L1-1; i > rank; i--)
653           primap_L1[i] = primap_L1[i-1];
654        primap_L1[rank].base = ent->base;
655        primap_L1[rank].ent  = ent;
656     }
657     
658     static inline PriMapEnt* maybe_find_in_primap ( Addr a )
659     {
660        PriMapEnt  key;
661        PriMapEnt* res;
662        Word       i;
663     
664        a &= ~(Addr)0xFFFF;
665     
666        /* First search the front-cache, which is a self-organising
667           list containing the most popular entries. */
668     
669        if (LIKELY(primap_L1[0].base == a))
670           return primap_L1[0].ent;
671        if (LIKELY(primap_L1[1].base == a)) {
672           Addr       t_base = primap_L1[0].base;
673           PriMapEnt* t_ent  = primap_L1[0].ent;
674           primap_L1[0].base = primap_L1[1].base;
675           primap_L1[0].ent  = primap_L1[1].ent;
676           primap_L1[1].base = t_base;
677           primap_L1[1].ent  = t_ent;
678           return primap_L1[0].ent;
679        }
680     
681        n_primap_L1_searches++;
682     
683        for (i = 0; i < N_PRIMAP_L1; i++) {
684           if (primap_L1[i].base == a) {
685              break;
686           }
687        }
688        tl_assert(i >= 0 && i <= N_PRIMAP_L1);
689     
690        n_primap_L1_cmps += (ULong)(i+1);
691     
692        if (i < N_PRIMAP_L1) {
693           if (i > 0) {
694              Addr       t_base = primap_L1[i-1].base;
695              PriMapEnt* t_ent  = primap_L1[i-1].ent;
696              primap_L1[i-1].base = primap_L1[i-0].base;
697              primap_L1[i-1].ent  = primap_L1[i-0].ent;
698              primap_L1[i-0].base = t_base;
699              primap_L1[i-0].ent  = t_ent;
700              i--;
701           }
702           return primap_L1[i].ent;
703        }
704     
705        n_primap_L2_searches++;
706     
707        /* First see if we already have it. */
708        key.base = a;
709        key.sm   = 0;
710     
711        res = VG_(OSetGen_Lookup)(primap_L2, &key);
712        if (res)
713           insert_into_primap_L1_at( PRIMAP_L1_INSERT_IX, res );
714        return res;
715     }
716     
717     static SecMap* alloc_secondary_map ( void )
718     {
719        SecMap* map;
720        UInt  i;
721     
722        // JRS 2008-June-25: what's the following assertion for?
723        tl_assert(0 == (sizeof(SecMap) % VKI_MAX_PAGE_SIZE));
724     
725        map = VG_(am_shadow_alloc)( sizeof(SecMap) );
726        if (map == NULL)
727           VG_(out_of_memory_NORETURN)( "annelid:allocate new SecMap",
728                                        sizeof(SecMap) );
729     
730        for (i = 0; i < SEC_MAP_WORDS; i++)
731           map->vseg[i] = NONPTR;
732        if (0) VG_(printf)("XXX new secmap %p\n", map);
733        return map;
734     }
735     
736     static PriMapEnt* find_or_alloc_in_primap ( Addr a )
737     {
738        PriMapEnt *nyu, *res;
739     
740        /* First see if we already have it. */
741        res = maybe_find_in_primap( a );
742        if (LIKELY(res))
743           return res;
744     
745        /* Ok, there's no entry in the secondary map, so we'll have
746           to allocate one. */
747        a &= ~(Addr)0xFFFF;
748     
749        nyu = (PriMapEnt*) VG_(OSetGen_AllocNode)( 
750                              primap_L2, sizeof(PriMapEnt) );
751        tl_assert(nyu);
752        nyu->base = a;
753        nyu->sm   = alloc_secondary_map();
754        tl_assert(nyu->sm);
755        VG_(OSetGen_Insert)( primap_L2, nyu );
756        insert_into_primap_L1_at( PRIMAP_L1_INSERT_IX, nyu );
757        n_primap_L2_nodes++;
758        return nyu;
759     }
760     
761     /////////////////////////////////////////////////
762     
763     // Nb: 'a' must be naturally word aligned for the host.
764     static inline Seg* get_mem_vseg ( Addr a )
765     {
766        SecMap* sm     = find_or_alloc_in_primap(a)->sm;
767        UWord   sm_off = (a & SHMEM_SECMAP_MASK) >> SHMEM_SECMAP_SHIFT;
768        tl_assert(SHMEM_IS_WORD_ALIGNED(a));
769        return sm->vseg[sm_off];
770     }
771     
772     // Nb: 'a' must be naturally word aligned for the host.
773     static inline void set_mem_vseg ( Addr a, Seg* vseg )
774     {
775        SecMap* sm     = find_or_alloc_in_primap(a)->sm;
776        UWord   sm_off = (a & SHMEM_SECMAP_MASK) >> SHMEM_SECMAP_SHIFT;
777        tl_assert(SHMEM_IS_WORD_ALIGNED(a));
778        sm->vseg[sm_off] = vseg;
779     }
780     
781     // Find the Seg which contains the given address.
782     // Returns UNKNOWN if no matches.  Never returns BOTTOM or NONPTR.
783     // Also, only returns in-use segments, not freed ones.
784     /* Doing this fast is distinctly difficult when there are more than a
785        few heap allocated blocks live.  Basically it is done by searching
786        addr_to_seg_map for 'a'.
787     
788        First, if 'a' is the start address of a segment, then we can detect
789        that by simply doing a VG_(lookupFM) of 'a', and we are done (nice
790        and easy).
791     
792        If 'a' is within some segment, but does not point to the start, it
793        is much more complex.  We use VG_(findBoundsFM) to find the segment
794        with the largest .addr field which is <= a, and we then inspect the
795        segment to see if 'a' really falls inside it or not.  This is all a
796        bit complex and fragile, and so there's a lot of assertery in the
797        code below.  It has been crosschecked however against the trivial
798        _SLOW implementation shown after the end of this fn.
799     */
800     static Seg* get_Seg_containing_addr( Addr a )
801     {
802        UWord keyW, valW;
803        Seg*  s2;
804     
805        /* Since we are going to poke around in it */
806        addr_to_seg_map_ENSURE_INIT();
807     
808        /* first, see if 'a' is at the start of a block.  We do this both
809           because it's easy and more imporantly because VG_(findBoundsFM)
810           will fail in this case, so we need to exclude it first. */
811        if (VG_(lookupFM)( addr_to_seg_map, &keyW, &valW, a )) {
812           tl_assert(keyW == a);
813           s2 = (Seg*)valW;
814           tl_assert(s2->addr == a);
815        } else {
816           Bool  ok;
817           UWord kMin, vMin, kMax, vMax;
818           Seg   minSeg;
819           Seg   maxSeg;
820           UWord minAddr = 0;
821           UWord maxAddr = ~minAddr;
822           VG_(memset)(&minSeg, 0, sizeof(minSeg));
823           VG_(memset)(&maxSeg, 0, sizeof(maxSeg));
824           minSeg.addr = minAddr;
825           maxSeg.addr = maxAddr;
826           ok = VG_(findBoundsFM)( addr_to_seg_map,
827                                   &kMin, &vMin, &kMax, &vMax,
828                                   minAddr, (UWord)&minSeg,
829                                   maxAddr, (UWord)&maxSeg, a );
830           tl_assert(ok); /* must be so, since False is only returned when
831                             'a' is directly present in the map, and we
832                             just established that it isn't. */
833           /* At this point, either vMin points at minSeg, or it points at a
834              real Seg.  In the former case, there is no live heap-allocated
835              Seg which has a start address <= a, so a is not in any block.
836              In the latter case, the Seg vMin points at may or may not
837              actually contain 'a'; we can only tell that by inspecting the
838              Seg itself. */
839           s2 = (Seg*)vMin;
840           tl_assert(kMin == s2->addr);
841           if (s2 == &minSeg) {
842              /* the former */
843              s2 = UNKNOWN;
844           } else {
845              /* the latter */
846              tl_assert(s2->addr <= a);
847              /* if s2 doesn't actually contain 'a', we must forget about it. */
848              if (s2->szB == 0 /* a zero sized block can't contain anything */
849                  || s2->addr + s2->szB < a /* the usual range check */)
850                 s2 = UNKNOWN;
851           }
852           /* while we're at it, do as much assertery as we can, since this
853              is all rather complex.  Either vMax points at maxSeg, or it
854              points to a real block, which must have a start address
855              greater than a. */
856           tl_assert(kMax == ((Seg*)vMax)->addr);
857           if (vMax == (UWord)&maxSeg) {
858              /* nothing we can check */
859           } else {
860              tl_assert(a < kMax); /* hence also a < ((Seg*)vMax)->addr */
861           }
862        }
863     
864        return s2;
865     }
866     
867     /* XXXX very slow reference implementation.  Do not use.
868     static Seg* get_Seg_containing_addr_SLOW( Addr a )
869     {
870        SegGroup* group;
871        UWord i;
872        stats__slow_searches++;
873        for (group = group_list; group; group = group->admin) {
874           for (i = 0; i < group->nextfree; i++) {
875              stats__slow_totcmps++;
876              if (Seg__is_freed(&group->segs[i]))
877                 continue;
878              if (group->segs[i].addr <= a
879                  && a < group->segs[i].addr + group->segs[i].szB)
880                 return &group->segs[i];
881           }
882        }
883        return UNKNOWN;
884     }
885     */
886

922     
923     void h_replace_free ( ThreadId tid, void* p )
924     {
925        // Should arguably check here if p.vseg matches the segID of the
926        // pointed-to block... unfortunately, by this stage, we don't know what
927        // p.vseg is, because we don't know the address of p (the p here is a
928        // copy, and we've lost the address of its source).  To do so would
929        // require passing &p in, which would require rewriting part of
930        // vg_replace_malloc.c... argh.
931        //
932        // However, Memcheck does free checking, and will catch almost all
933        // violations this checking would have caught.  (Would only miss if we
934        // unluckily passed an unrelated pointer to the very start of a heap
935        // block that was unrelated to that block.  This is very unlikely!)    So
936        // we haven't lost much.
937     
938        handle_free_heap(tid, p);
939     }
940     
941     void h_replace___builtin_delete ( ThreadId tid, void* p )
942     {
943        handle_free_heap(tid, p);
944     }
945     
946     void h_replace___builtin_vec_delete ( ThreadId tid, void* p )
947     {
948        handle_free_heap(tid, p);
949     }
950     
951     void* h_replace_realloc ( ThreadId tid, void* p_old, SizeT new_size )
952     {
953        Seg* seg;
954     
955        /* First try and find the block. */
956        seg = find_Seg_by_addr( (Addr)p_old );
957        if (!seg)
958           return NULL;
959     
960        tl_assert(seg->addr == (Addr)p_old);
961     
962        if (new_size <= seg->szB) {
963           /* new size is smaller: allocate, copy from old to new */
964           Addr p_new = (Addr)VG_(cli_malloc)(VG_(clo_alignment), new_size);
965           VG_(memcpy)((void*)p_new, p_old, new_size);
966     
967           /* Notification: copy retained part */
968           copy_mem       ( (Addr)p_old, p_new, new_size );
969     
970           /* Free old memory */
971           die_and_free_mem_heap( tid, seg );
972     
973           /* This has to be after die_and_free_mem_heap, otherwise the
974              former succeeds in shorting out the new block, not the
975              old, in the case when both are on the same list.  */
976           add_new_segment ( tid, p_new, new_size );
977     
978           return (void*)p_new;
979        } else {
980           /* new size is bigger: allocate, copy from old to new */
981           Addr p_new = (Addr)VG_(cli_malloc)(VG_(clo_alignment), new_size);
982           VG_(memcpy)((void*)p_new, p_old, seg->szB);
983     
984           /* Notification: first half kept and copied, second half new */
985           copy_mem       ( (Addr)p_old, p_new, seg->szB );
986           set_mem_unknown( p_new + seg->szB, new_size - seg->szB );
987     
988           /* Free old memory */
989           die_and_free_mem_heap( tid, seg );
990     
991           /* This has to be after die_and_free_mem_heap, otherwise the
992              former succeeds in shorting out the new block, not the old,
993              in the case when both are on the same list.  NB jrs
994              2008-Sept-11: not sure if this comment is valid/correct any
995              more -- I suspect not. */
996           add_new_segment ( tid, p_new, new_size );
997     
998           return (void*)p_new;
999        }
1000     }
1001     
1002     SizeT h_replace_malloc_usable_size ( ThreadId tid, void* p )
1003     {
1004        Seg* seg = find_Seg_by_addr( (Addr)p );
1005     
1006        // There may be slop, but pretend there isn't because only the asked-for
1007        // area will have been shadowed properly.
1008        return ( seg ? seg->szB : 0 );
1009     }

1016     static inline
1017     void set_mem ( Addr a, SizeT len, Seg* seg )
1018     {
1019        Addr end;
1020     
1021        if (0 == len)
1022           return;
1023     
1024        if (len > 100 * 1000 * 1000)
1025           VG_(message)(Vg_UserMsg,
1026                        "Warning: set address range state: large range %lu\n",
1027                        len);
1028     
1029        a   = VG_ROUNDDN(a,       sizeof(UWord));
1030        end = VG_ROUNDUP(a + len, sizeof(UWord));
1031        for ( ; a < end; a += sizeof(UWord))
1032           set_mem_vseg(a, seg);
1033     }
1034     
1035     static void set_mem_unknown( Addr a, SizeT len )
1036     {
1037        set_mem( a, len, UNKNOWN );
1038     }

1125     
1126     static void copy_mem( Addr from, Addr to, SizeT len )
1127     {
1128        Addr fromend = from + len;
1129     
1130        // Must be aligned due to malloc always returning aligned objects.
1131        tl_assert(VG_IS_8_ALIGNED(from) && VG_IS_8_ALIGNED(to));
1132     
1133        // Must only be called with positive len.
1134        if (0 == len)
1135           return;
1136     
1137        for ( ; from < fromend; from += sizeof(UWord), to += sizeof(UWord))
1138           set_mem_vseg( to, get_mem_vseg(from) );
1139     }

1145     //zz }

1147     //zz static void die_mem_brk( Addr a, UInt len )

1149     //zz    set_mem_unknown(a, len);

1151     //zz }
1152     
1153     void h_die_mem_munmap( Addr a, SizeT len )
1154     {
1155     //   handle_free_munmap( (void*)a, len );
1156     }
1157     
1158     // Don't need to check all addresses within the block; in the absence of
1159     // discontiguous segments, the segments for the first and last bytes should
1160     // be the same.  Can't easily check the pointer segment matches the block
1161     // segment, unfortunately, but the first/last check should catch most
1162     // errors.
1163     static void pre_mem_access2 ( CorePart part, ThreadId tid, Char* str,
1164                                   Addr s/*tart*/, Addr e/*nd*/ )
1165     {
1166        Seg  *seglo, *seghi;
1167     
1168        // Don't check code being translated -- very slow, and not much point
1169        if (Vg_CoreTranslate == part) return;
1170     
1171        // Don't check the signal case -- only happens in core, no need to check
1172        if (Vg_CoreSignal == part) return;
1173     
1174        // Only expect syscalls after this point
1175        if (part != Vg_CoreSysCall) {
1176           VG_(printf)("part = %d\n", part);
1177           VG_(tool_panic)("unknown corepart in pre_mem_access2");
1178        }
1179     
1180        // Check first and last bytes match
1181        seglo = get_Seg_containing_addr( s );
1182        seghi = get_Seg_containing_addr( e );
1183        tl_assert( BOTTOM != seglo && NONPTR != seglo );
1184        tl_assert( BOTTOM != seghi && NONPTR != seghi );
1185     
1186        /* record an error if start and end are in different, but known segments */
1187        if (is_known_segment(seglo) && is_known_segment(seghi)
1188            && seglo != seghi) {
1189           h_record_sysparam_error(tid, part, str, s, e, seglo, seghi);
1190        }
1191        else
1192        /* record an error if start is in a known segment but end isn't */
1193        if (is_known_segment(seglo) && !is_known_segment(seghi)) {
1194           h_record_sysparam_error(tid, part, str, s, e, seglo, UNKNOWN);
1195        }
1196        else
1197        /* record an error if end is in a known segment but start isn't */
1198        if (!is_known_segment(seglo) && is_known_segment(seghi)) {
1199           h_record_sysparam_error(tid, part, str, s, e, UNKNOWN, seghi);
1200        }
1201     }
1202     
1203     void h_pre_mem_access ( CorePart part, ThreadId tid, Char* s,
1204                             Addr base, SizeT size )
1205     {
1206        pre_mem_access2( part, tid, s, base, base + size - 1 );
1207     }
1208     
1209     void h_pre_mem_read_asciiz ( CorePart part, ThreadId tid, 
1210                                  Char* s, Addr lo )
1211     {
1212        Addr hi = lo;
1213     
1214        // Nb: the '\0' must be included in the lo...hi range
1215        while ('\0' != *(Char*)hi) hi++;
1216        pre_mem_access2( part, tid, s, lo, hi );
1217     }

1238     // BEGIN move this uglyness to pc_machine.c
1239     
1240     static inline Bool host_is_big_endian ( void ) {
1241        UInt x = 0x11223344;
1242        return 0x1122 == *(UShort*)(&x);
1243     }
1244     static inline Bool host_is_little_endian ( void ) {
1245        UInt x = 0x11223344;
1246        return 0x3344 == *(UShort*)(&x);
1247     }
1248     
1249     #define N_INTREGINFO_OFFSETS 4
1250     
1251     /* Holds the result of a query to 'get_IntRegInfo'.  Valid values for
1252        n_offsets are:
1253     
1254        -1: means the queried guest state slice exactly matches
1255            one integer register
1256     
1257        0: means the queried guest state slice does not overlap any
1258           integer registers
1259     
1260        1 .. N_INTREGINFO_OFFSETS: means the queried guest state offset
1261           overlaps n_offsets different integer registers, and their base
1262           offsets are placed in the offsets array.
1263     */
1264     typedef
1265        struct {
1266           Int offsets[N_INTREGINFO_OFFSETS];
1267           Int n_offsets;
1268        }
1269        IntRegInfo;

1279     # define PC_SIZEOF_GUEST_STATE sizeof(VexGuestAMD64State)
1280     # define PC_OFF_FS_ZERO offsetof(VexGuestAMD64State,guest_FS_ZERO)
1281     # define PC_SZB_FS_ZERO sizeof( ((VexGuestAMD64State*)0)->guest_FS_ZERO)
1282     #endif

1285     # include "libvex_guest_ppc32.h"
1286     # define PC_SIZEOF_GUEST_STATE sizeof(VexGuestPPC32State)
1287     #endif

1304     
1305     /* See description on definition of type IntRegInfo. */
1306     static void get_IntRegInfo ( /*OUT*/IntRegInfo* iii, Int offset, Int szB )
1307     {
1308        /* --------------------- x86 --------------------- */
1309     
1310     #  if defined(VGA_x86)
1311     
1312     #  define GOF(_fieldname) \
1313           (offsetof(VexGuestX86State,guest_##_fieldname))
1314     
1315        Int  o    = offset;
1316        Int  sz   = szB;
1317        Bool is4  = sz == 4;
1318        Bool is21 = sz == 2 || sz == 1;
1319     
1320        tl_assert(sz > 0);
1321        tl_assert(host_is_little_endian());
1322     
1323        /* Set default state to "does not intersect any int register". */
1324        VG_(memset)( iii, 0, sizeof(*iii) );
1325     
1326        /* Exact accesses to integer registers */
1327        if (o == GOF(EAX)     && is4) goto exactly1;
1328        if (o == GOF(ECX)     && is4) goto exactly1;
1329        if (o == GOF(EDX)     && is4) goto exactly1;
1330        if (o == GOF(EBX)     && is4) goto exactly1;
1331        if (o == GOF(ESP)     && is4) goto exactly1;
1332        if (o == GOF(EBP)     && is4) goto exactly1;
1333        if (o == GOF(ESI)     && is4) goto exactly1;
1334        if (o == GOF(EDI)     && is4) goto exactly1;
1335        if (o == GOF(EIP)     && is4) goto none;
1336        if (o == GOF(IP_AT_SYSCALL) && is4) goto none;
1337        if (o == GOF(CC_OP)   && is4) goto none;
1338        if (o == GOF(CC_DEP1) && is4) goto none;
1339        if (o == GOF(CC_DEP2) && is4) goto none;
1340        if (o == GOF(CC_NDEP) && is4) goto none;
1341        if (o == GOF(DFLAG)   && is4) goto none;
1342        if (o == GOF(IDFLAG)  && is4) goto none;
1343        if (o == GOF(ACFLAG)  && is4) goto none;
1344     
1345        /* Partial accesses to integer registers */
1346        if (o == GOF(EAX)     && is21) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1347        if (o == GOF(EAX)+1   && is21) { o -= 1; o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1348        if (o == GOF(ECX)     && is21) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1349        if (o == GOF(ECX)+1   && is21) { o -= 1; o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1350        if (o == GOF(EBX)     && is21) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1351        if (o == GOF(EBX)+1   && is21) { o -= 1; o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1352        if (o == GOF(EDX)     && is21) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1353        if (o == GOF(EDX)+1   && is21) { o -= 1; o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1354        if (o == GOF(ESI)     && is21) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1355        if (o == GOF(EDI)     && is21) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1356     
1357        /* Segment related guff */
1358        if (o == GOF(GS)  && sz == 2) goto none;
1359        if (o == GOF(LDT) && is4) goto none;
1360        if (o == GOF(GDT) && is4) goto none;
1361     
1362        /* FP admin related */
1363        if (o == GOF(SSEROUND) && is4) goto none;
1364        if (o == GOF(FPROUND)  && is4) goto none;
1365        if (o == GOF(EMWARN)   && is4) goto none;
1366        if (o == GOF(FTOP)     && is4) goto none;
1367        if (o == GOF(FPTAG)    && sz == 8) goto none;
1368        if (o == GOF(FC3210)   && is4) goto none;
1369     
1370        /* xmm registers, including arbitrary sub-parts */
1371        if (o >= GOF(XMM0) && o+sz <= GOF(XMM0)+16) goto none;
1372        if (o >= GOF(XMM1) && o+sz <= GOF(XMM1)+16) goto none;
1373        if (o >= GOF(XMM2) && o+sz <= GOF(XMM2)+16) goto none;
1374        if (o >= GOF(XMM3) && o+sz <= GOF(XMM3)+16) goto none;
1375        if (o >= GOF(XMM4) && o+sz <= GOF(XMM4)+16) goto none;
1376        if (o >= GOF(XMM5) && o+sz <= GOF(XMM5)+16) goto none;
1377        if (o >= GOF(XMM6) && o+sz <= GOF(XMM6)+16) goto none;
1378        if (o >= GOF(XMM7) && o+sz <= GOF(XMM7)+16) goto none;
1379     
1380        /* mmx/x87 registers (a bit of a kludge, since 'o' is not checked
1381           to be exactly equal to one of FPREG[0] .. FPREG[7]) */
1382        if (o >= GOF(FPREG[0]) && o < GOF(FPREG[7])+8 && sz == 8) goto none;
1383     
1384        /* the entire mmx/x87 register bank in one big piece */
1385        if (o == GOF(FPREG) && sz == 64) goto none;
1386     
1387        VG_(printf)("get_IntRegInfo(x86):failing on (%d,%d)\n", o, sz);
1388        tl_assert(0);
1389     #  undef GOF
1390     
1391        /* -------------------- amd64 -------------------- */
1392     
1393     #  elif defined(VGA_amd64)
1394     
1395     #  define GOF(_fieldname) \
1396           (offsetof(VexGuestAMD64State,guest_##_fieldname))
1397     
1398        Int  o     = offset;
1399        Int  sz    = szB;
1400        Bool is421 = sz == 4 || sz == 2 || sz == 1;
1401        Bool is8   = sz == 8;
1402     
1403        tl_assert(sz > 0);
1404        tl_assert(host_is_little_endian());
1405     
1406        /* Set default state to "does not intersect any int register". */
1407        VG_(memset)( iii, 0, sizeof(*iii) );
1408     
1409        /* Exact accesses to integer registers */
1410        if (o == GOF(RAX)     && is8) goto exactly1;
1411        if (o == GOF(RCX)     && is8) goto exactly1;
1412        if (o == GOF(RDX)     && is8) goto exactly1;
1413        if (o == GOF(RBX)     && is8) goto exactly1;
1414        if (o == GOF(RSP)     && is8) goto exactly1;
1415        if (o == GOF(RBP)     && is8) goto exactly1;
1416        if (o == GOF(RSI)     && is8) goto exactly1;
1417        if (o == GOF(RDI)     && is8) goto exactly1;
1418        if (o == GOF(R8)      && is8) goto exactly1;
1419        if (o == GOF(R9)      && is8) goto exactly1;
1420        if (o == GOF(R10)     && is8) goto exactly1;
1421        if (o == GOF(R11)     && is8) goto exactly1;
1422        if (o == GOF(R12)     && is8) goto exactly1;
1423        if (o == GOF(R13)     && is8) goto exactly1;
1424        if (o == GOF(R14)     && is8) goto exactly1;
1425        if (o == GOF(R15)     && is8) goto exactly1;
1426        if (o == GOF(RIP)     && is8) goto exactly1;
1427        if (o == GOF(IP_AT_SYSCALL) && is8) goto none;
1428        if (o == GOF(CC_OP)   && is8) goto none;
1429        if (o == GOF(CC_DEP1) && is8) goto none;
1430        if (o == GOF(CC_DEP2) && is8) goto none;
1431        if (o == GOF(CC_NDEP) && is8) goto none;
1432        if (o == GOF(DFLAG)   && is8) goto none;
1433        if (o == GOF(IDFLAG)  && is8) goto none;
1434     
1435        /* Partial accesses to integer registers */
1436        if (o == GOF(RAX)     && is421) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1437        if (o == GOF(RAX)+1   && is421) { o -= 1; o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1438        if (o == GOF(RCX)     && is421) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1439        if (o == GOF(RCX)+1   && is421) { o -= 1; o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1440        if (o == GOF(RDX)     && is421) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1441        if (o == GOF(RDX)+1   && is421) { o -= 1; o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1442        if (o == GOF(RBX)     && is421) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1443        if (o == GOF(RBX)+1   && is421) { o -= 1; o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1444        if (o == GOF(RBP)     && is421) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1445        if (o == GOF(RSI)     && is421) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1446        if (o == GOF(RDI)     && is421) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1447        if (o == GOF(R8)      && is421) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1448        if (o == GOF(R9)      && is421) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1449        if (o == GOF(R10)     && is421) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1450        if (o == GOF(R11)     && is421) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1451        if (o == GOF(R12)     && is421) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1452        if (o == GOF(R13)     && is421) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1453        if (o == GOF(R14)     && is421) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1454        if (o == GOF(R15)     && is421) {         o -= 0; goto contains_o; }
1455     
1456        /* Segment related guff */
1457        if (o == GOF(FS_ZERO) && is8) goto exactly1;
1458     
1459        /* FP admin related */
1460        if (o == GOF(SSEROUND) && is8) goto none;
1461        if (o == GOF(FPROUND)  && is8) goto none;
1462        if (o == GOF(EMWARN)   && sz == 4) goto none;
1463        if (o == GOF(FTOP)     && sz == 4) goto none;
1464        if (o == GOF(FPTAG)    && is8) goto none;
1465        if (o == GOF(FC3210)   && is8) goto none;
1466     
1467        /* xmm registers, including arbitrary sub-parts */
1468        if (o >= GOF(XMM0)  && o+sz <= GOF(XMM0)+16)  goto none;
1469        if (o >= GOF(XMM1)  && o+sz <= GOF(XMM1)+16)  goto none;
1470        if (o >= GOF(XMM2)  && o+sz <= GOF(XMM2)+16)  goto none;
1471        if (o >= GOF(XMM3)  && o+sz <= GOF(XMM3)+16)  goto none;
1472        if (o >= GOF(XMM4)  && o+sz <= GOF(XMM4)+16)  goto none;
1473        if (o >= GOF(XMM5)  && o+sz <= GOF(XMM5)+16)  goto none;
1474        if (o >= GOF(XMM6)  && o+sz <= GOF(XMM6)+16)  goto none;
1475        if (o >= GOF(XMM7)  && o+sz <= GOF(XMM7)+16)  goto none;
1476        if (o >= GOF(XMM8)  && o+sz <= GOF(XMM8)+16)  goto none;
1477        if (o >= GOF(XMM9)  && o+sz <= GOF(XMM9)+16)  goto none;
1478        if (o >= GOF(XMM10) && o+sz <= GOF(XMM10)+16) goto none;
1479        if (o >= GOF(XMM11) && o+sz <= GOF(XMM11)+16) goto none;
1480        if (o >= GOF(XMM12) && o+sz <= GOF(XMM12)+16) goto none;
1481        if (o >= GOF(XMM13) && o+sz <= GOF(XMM13)+16) goto none;
1482        if (o >= GOF(XMM14) && o+sz <= GOF(XMM14)+16) goto none;
1483        if (o >= GOF(XMM15) && o+sz <= GOF(XMM15)+16) goto none;
1484     
1485        /* mmx/x87 registers (a bit of a kludge, since 'o' is not checked
1486           to be exactly equal to one of FPREG[0] .. FPREG[7]) */
1487        if (o >= GOF(FPREG[0]) && o < GOF(FPREG[7])+8 && sz == 8) goto none;
1488     
1489        VG_(printf)("get_IntRegInfo(amd64):failing on (%d,%d)\n", o, sz);
1490        tl_assert(0);
1491     #  undef GOF
1492     
1493        /* -------------------- ppc32 -------------------- */
1494     
1495     #  elif defined(VGA_ppc32)
1496     
1497     #  define GOF(_fieldname) \
1498           (offsetof(VexGuestPPC32State,guest_##_fieldname))
1499     
1500        Int  o    = offset;
1501        Int  sz   = szB;
1502        Bool is4  = sz == 4;
1503        Bool is8  = sz == 8;
1504     
1505        tl_assert(sz > 0);
1506        tl_assert(host_is_big_endian());
1507     
1508        /* Set default state to "does not intersect any int register". */
1509        VG_(memset)( iii, 0, sizeof(*iii) );
1510     
1511        /* Exact accesses to integer registers */
1512        if (o == GOF(GPR0)  && is4) goto exactly1;
1513        if (o == GOF(GPR1)  && is4) goto exactly1;
1514        if (o == GOF(GPR2)  && is4) goto exactly1;
1515        if (o == GOF(GPR3)  && is4) goto exactly1;
1516        if (o == GOF(GPR4)  && is4) goto exactly1;
1517        if (o == GOF(GPR5)  && is4) goto exactly1;
1518        if (o == GOF(GPR6)  && is4) goto exactly1;
1519        if (o == GOF(GPR7)  && is4) goto exactly1;
1520        if (o == GOF(GPR8)  && is4) goto exactly1;
1521        if (o == GOF(GPR9)  && is4) goto exactly1;
1522        if (o == GOF(GPR10) && is4) goto exactly1;
1523        if (o == GOF(GPR11) && is4) goto exactly1;
1524        if (o == GOF(GPR12) && is4) goto exactly1;
1525        if (o == GOF(GPR13) && is4) goto exactly1;
1526        if (o == GOF(GPR14) && is4) goto exactly1;
1527        if (o == GOF(GPR15) && is4) goto exactly1;
1528        if (o == GOF(GPR16) && is4) goto exactly1;
1529        if (o == GOF(GPR17) && is4) goto exactly1;
1530        if (o == GOF(GPR18) && is4) goto exactly1;
1531        if (o == GOF(GPR19) && is4) goto exactly1;
1532        if (o == GOF(GPR20) && is4) goto exactly1;
1533        if (o == GOF(GPR21) && is4) goto exactly1;
1534        if (o == GOF(GPR22) && is4) goto exactly1;
1535        if (o == GOF(GPR23) && is4) goto exactly1;
1536        if (o == GOF(GPR24) && is4) goto exactly1;
1537        if (o == GOF(GPR25) && is4) goto exactly1;
1538        if (o == GOF(GPR26) && is4) goto exactly1;
1539        if (o == GOF(GPR27) && is4) goto exactly1;
1540        if (o == GOF(GPR28) && is4) goto exactly1;
1541        if (o == GOF(GPR29) && is4) goto exactly1;
1542        if (o == GOF(GPR30) && is4) goto exactly1;
1543        if (o == GOF(GPR31) && is4) goto exactly1;
1544     
1545        /* Misc integer reg and condition code accesses */
1546        if (o == GOF(LR)        && is4) goto exactly1;
1547        if (o == GOF(CTR)       && is4) goto exactly1;
1548        if (o == GOF(CIA)       && is4) goto none;
1549        if (o == GOF(IP_AT_SYSCALL) && is4) goto none;
1550        if (o == GOF(TISTART)   && is4) goto none;
1551        if (o == GOF(TILEN)     && is4) goto none;
1552        if (o == GOF(REDIR_SP)  && is4) goto none;
1553     
1554        if (sz == 1) {
1555           if (o == GOF(XER_SO))  goto none;
1556           if (o == GOF(XER_OV))  goto none;
1557           if (o == GOF(XER_CA))  goto none;
1558           if (o == GOF(XER_BC))  goto none;
1559           if (o == GOF(CR0_321)) goto none;
1560           if (o == GOF(CR0_0))   goto none;
1561           if (o == GOF(CR1_321)) goto none;
1562           if (o == GOF(CR1_0))   goto none;
1563           if (o == GOF(CR2_321)) goto none;
1564           if (o == GOF(CR2_0))   goto none;
1565           if (o == GOF(CR3_321)) goto none;
1566           if (o == GOF(CR3_0))   goto none;
1567           if (o == GOF(CR4_321)) goto none;
1568           if (o == GOF(CR4_0))   goto none;
1569           if (o == GOF(CR5_321)) goto none;
1570           if (o == GOF(CR5_0))   goto none;
1571           if (o == GOF(CR6_321)) goto none;
1572           if (o == GOF(CR6_0))   goto none;
1573           if (o == GOF(CR7_321)) goto none;
1574           if (o == GOF(CR7_0))   goto none;
1575        }
1576     
1577        /* Exact accesses to FP registers */
1578        if (o == GOF(FPR0)  && is8) goto none;
1579        if (o == GOF(FPR1)  && is8) goto none;
1580        if (o == GOF(FPR2)  && is8) goto none;
1581        if (o == GOF(FPR3)  && is8) goto none;
1582        if (o == GOF(FPR4)  && is8) goto none;
1583        if (o == GOF(FPR5)  && is8) goto none;
1584        if (o == GOF(FPR6)  && is8) goto none;
1585        if (o == GOF(FPR7)  && is8) goto none;
1586        if (o == GOF(FPR8)  && is8) goto none;
1587        if (o == GOF(FPR9)  && is8) goto none;
1588        if (o == GOF(FPR10) && is8) goto none;
1589        if (o == GOF(FPR11) && is8) goto none;
1590        if (o == GOF(FPR12) && is8) goto none;
1591        if (o == GOF(FPR13) && is8) goto none;
1592        if (o == GOF(FPR14) && is8) goto none;
1593        if (o == GOF(FPR15) && is8) goto none;
1594        if (o == GOF(FPR16) && is8) goto none;
1595        if (o == GOF(FPR17) && is8) goto none;
1596        if (o == GOF(FPR18) && is8) goto none;
1597        if (o == GOF(FPR19) && is8) goto none;
1598        if (o == GOF(FPR20) && is8) goto none;
1599        if (o == GOF(FPR21) && is8) goto none;
1600        if (o == GOF(FPR22) && is8) goto none;

1807        if (o == GOF(VR28) && sz == 16) goto none;
1808        if (o == GOF(VR29) && sz == 16) goto none;
1809        if (o == GOF(VR30) && sz == 16) goto none;
1810        if (o == GOF(VR31) && sz == 16) goto none;

1814     
1815        VG_(printf)("get_IntRegInfo(ppc64):failing on (%d,%d)\n", o, sz);
1816        tl_assert(0);
1817     #  undef GOF
1818     
1819        /* -------------------- arm -------------------- */
1820     
1821     #  elif defined(VGA_arm)
1822     
1823     #  define GOF(_fieldname) \
1824           (offsetof(VexGuestARMState,guest_##_fieldname))
1825     
1826        Int  o    = offset;
1827        Int  sz   = szB;
1828        //Bool is4  = sz == 4;
1829        //Bool is8  = sz == 8;
1830     
1831        tl_assert(sz > 0);
1832        tl_assert(host_is_big_endian());

1835        VG_(memset)( iii, 0, sizeof(*iii) );

1851     #  endif
1852     
1853       exactly1:
1854        iii->n_offsets = -1;
1855        return;
1856       none:
1857        iii->n_offsets = 0;
1858        return;
1859       contains_o:
1860        tl_assert(o >= 0 && 0 == (o % sizeof(UWord)));
1861        iii->n_offsets = 1;
1862        iii->offsets[0] = o;
1863        return;
1864     }

1866     
1867     /* Does 'arr' describe an indexed guest state section containing host
1868        words, that we want to shadow? */
1869     
1870     static Bool is_integer_guest_reg_array ( IRRegArray* arr )
1871     {
1872        /* --------------------- x86 --------------------- */
1873     #  if defined(VGA_x86)
1874        /* The x87 tag array. */
1875        if (arr->base == offsetof(VexGuestX86State,guest_FPTAG[0])
1876            && arr->elemTy == Ity_I8 && arr->nElems == 8)
1877           return False;
1878        /* The x87 register array. */
1879        if (arr->base == offsetof(VexGuestX86State,guest_FPREG[0])
1880            && arr->elemTy == Ity_F64 && arr->nElems == 8)
1881           return False;
1882     
1883        VG_(printf)("is_integer_guest_reg_array(x86): unhandled: ");
1884        ppIRRegArray(arr);
1885        VG_(printf)("\n");
1886        tl_assert(0);
1887     
1888        /* -------------------- amd64 -------------------- */
1889     #  elif defined(VGA_amd64)
1890        /* The x87 tag array. */
1891        if (arr->base == offsetof(VexGuestAMD64State,guest_FPTAG[0])
1892            && arr->elemTy == Ity_I8 && arr->nElems == 8)
1893           return False;
1894        /* The x87 register array. */
1895        if (arr->base == offsetof(VexGuestAMD64State,guest_FPREG[0])
1896            && arr->elemTy == Ity_F64 && arr->nElems == 8)
1897           return False;
1898     
1899        VG_(printf)("is_integer_guest_reg_array(amd64): unhandled: ");
1900        ppIRRegArray(arr);
1901        VG_(printf)("\n");
1902        tl_assert(0);
1903     
1904        /* -------------------- ppc32 -------------------- */
1905     #  elif defined(VGA_ppc32)
1906        /* The redir stack. */
1907        if (arr->base == offsetof(VexGuestPPC32State,guest_REDIR_STACK[0])
1908            && arr->elemTy == Ity_I32
1909            && arr->nElems == VEX_GUEST_PPC32_REDIR_STACK_SIZE)
1910           return True;
1911     
1912        VG_(printf)("is_integer_guest_reg_array(ppc32): unhandled: ");
1913        ppIRRegArray(arr);
1914        VG_(printf)("\n");
1915        tl_assert(0);
1916     
1917        /* -------------------- ppc64 -------------------- */
1918     #  elif defined(VGA_ppc64)
1919        /* The redir stack. */
1920        if (arr->base == offsetof(VexGuestPPC64State,guest_REDIR_STACK[0])
1921            && arr->elemTy == Ity_I64
1922            && arr->nElems == VEX_GUEST_PPC64_REDIR_STACK_SIZE)
1923           return True;
1924     
1925        VG_(printf)("is_integer_guest_reg_array(ppc64): unhandled: ");
1926        ppIRRegArray(arr);
1927        VG_(printf)("\n");
1928        tl_assert(0);
1929     
1930        /* -------------------- s390x -------------------- */
1931     #  elif defined(VGA_s390x)
1932     
1933        tl_assert(0);
1934     
1935        /* -------------------- arm -------------------- */
1936     #  elif defined(VGA_arm)
1937        /* There are no rotating register sections on ARM. */
1938        VG_(printf)("is_integer_guest_reg_array(arm): unhandled: ");
1939        ppIRRegArray(arr);
1940        VG_(printf)("\n");
1941        tl_assert(0);
1942     
1943     #  else
1944     #    error "FIXME: not implemented for this architecture"
1945     #  endif
1946     }

1949     // END move this uglyness to pc_machine.c
1950     
1951     /* returns True iff given slice exactly matches an int reg.  Merely
1952        a convenience wrapper around get_IntRegInfo. */
1953     static Bool is_integer_guest_reg ( Int offset, Int szB )
1954     {
1955        IntRegInfo iii;
1956        get_IntRegInfo( &iii, offset, szB );
1957        tl_assert(iii.n_offsets >= -1 && iii.n_offsets <= N_INTREGINFO_OFFSETS);
1958        return iii.n_offsets == -1;
1959     }
1960     
1961     /* these assume guest and host have the same endianness and
1962        word size (probably). */
1963     static UWord get_guest_intreg ( ThreadId tid, Int shadowNo,
1964                                     PtrdiffT offset, SizeT size )
1965     {
1966        UChar tmp[ 2 + sizeof(UWord) ];
1967        tl_assert(size == sizeof(UWord));
1968        tl_assert(0 == (offset % sizeof(UWord)));
1969        VG_(memset)(tmp, 0, sizeof(tmp));
1970        tmp[0] = 0x31;
1971        tmp[ sizeof(tmp)-1 ] = 0x27;
1972        VG_(get_shadow_regs_area)(tid, &tmp[1], shadowNo, offset, size);
1973        tl_assert(tmp[0] == 0x31);
1974        tl_assert(tmp[ sizeof(tmp)-1 ] == 0x27);
1975        return * ((UWord*) &tmp[1] ); /* MISALIGNED LOAD */
1976     }
1977     static void put_guest_intreg ( ThreadId tid, Int shadowNo,
1978                                    PtrdiffT offset, SizeT size, UWord w )
1979     {
1980        tl_assert(size == sizeof(UWord));
1981        tl_assert(0 == (offset % sizeof(UWord)));
1982        VG_(set_shadow_regs_area)(tid, shadowNo, offset, size,
1983                                  (const UChar*)&w);
1984     }
1985     
1986     /* Initialise the integer shadow registers to UNKNOWN.  This is a bit
1987        of a nasty kludge, but it does mean we don't need to know which
1988        registers we really need to initialise -- simply assume that all
1989        integer registers will be naturally aligned w.r.t. the start of the
1990        guest state, and fill in all possible entries. */
1991     static void init_shadow_registers ( ThreadId tid )
1992     {
1993        Int i, wordSzB = sizeof(UWord);
1994        for (i = 0; i < PC_SIZEOF_GUEST_STATE-wordSzB; i += wordSzB) {
1995           put_guest_intreg( tid, 1, i, wordSzB, (UWord)UNKNOWN );
1996        }
1997     }
1998     
1999     static void post_reg_write_nonptr ( ThreadId tid, PtrdiffT offset, SizeT size )
2000     {
2001        // syscall_return: Default is non-pointer.  If it really is a pointer
2002        // (eg. for mmap()), SK_(post_syscall) sets it again afterwards.
2003        //
2004        // clientreq_return: All the global client requests return non-pointers
2005        // (except possibly CLIENT_CALL[0123], but they're handled by
2006        // post_reg_write_clientcall, not here).
2007        //
2008        if (is_integer_guest_reg( (Int)offset, (Int)size )) {
2009           put_guest_intreg( tid, 1, offset, size, (UWord)NONPTR );
2010        } 
2011        else 
2012        if (size == 1 || size == 2) {
2013           /* can't possibly be an integer guest reg.  Ignore. */
2014        }
2015        else {
2016           // DDD: on Darwin, this assertion fails because we currently do a
2017           // 'post_reg_write' on the 'guest_CC_DEP1' pseudo-register.
2018           // JRS 2009July13: we should change is_integer_guest_reg()
2019           // to accept guest_CC_DEP* and guest_CC_NDEP
2020           // as legitimate pointer-holding registers
2021           tl_assert(0);
2022        }
2023        //   VG_(set_thread_shadow_archreg)( tid, reg, (UInt)NONPTR );
2024     }
2025     
2026     static void post_reg_write_nonptr_or_unknown ( ThreadId tid,
2027                                                    PtrdiffT offset, SizeT size )
2028     {
2029        // deliver_signal: called from two places; one sets the reg to zero, the
2030        // other sets the stack pointer.
2031        //
2032        if (is_integer_guest_reg( (Int)offset, (Int)size )) {
2033           put_guest_intreg(
2034              tid, 1/*shadowno*/, offset, size,
2035              (UWord)nonptr_or_unknown( 
2036                        get_guest_intreg( tid, 0/*shadowno*/,
2037                                          offset, size )));
2038        } else {
2039           tl_assert(0);
2040        }
2041     }
2042     
2043     void h_post_reg_write_demux ( CorePart part, ThreadId tid,
2044                                   PtrdiffT guest_state_offset, SizeT size)
2045     {
2046        if (0)
2047        VG_(printf)("post_reg_write_demux: tid %d part %d off %ld size %ld\n",
2048                    (Int)tid, (Int)part,
2049                   guest_state_offset, size);
2050        switch (part) {
2051           case Vg_CoreStartup:
2052              /* This is a bit of a kludge since for any Vg_CoreStartup
2053                 event we overwrite the entire shadow register set.  But
2054                 that's ok - we're only called once with
2055                 part==Vg_CoreStartup event, and in that case the supplied
2056                 offset & size cover the entire guest state anyway. */
2057              init_shadow_registers(tid);
2058              break;
2059           case Vg_CoreSysCall:
2060              if (0) VG_(printf)("ZZZZZZZ p_r_w    -> NONPTR\n");
2061              post_reg_write_nonptr( tid, guest_state_offset, size );
2062              break;
2063           case Vg_CoreClientReq:
2064              post_reg_write_nonptr( tid, guest_state_offset, size );
2065              break;
2066           case Vg_CoreSignal:
2067              post_reg_write_nonptr_or_unknown( tid, guest_state_offset, size );
2068              break;
2069           default:
2070              tl_assert(0);
2071        }
2072     }
2073     
2074     void h_post_reg_write_clientcall(ThreadId tid, PtrdiffT guest_state_offset,
2075                                      SizeT size, Addr f )
2076     {
2077        UWord p;
2078     
2079        // Having to do this is a bit nasty...
2080        if (f == (Addr)h_replace_malloc
2081            || f == (Addr)h_replace___builtin_new
2082            || f == (Addr)h_replace___builtin_vec_new
2083            || f == (Addr)h_replace_calloc
2084            || f == (Addr)h_replace_memalign
2085            || f == (Addr)h_replace_realloc)
2086        {
2087           // We remembered the last added segment;  make sure it's the right one.
2088           /* What's going on: at this point, the scheduler has just called
2089              'f' -- one of our malloc replacement functions -- and it has
2090              returned.  The return value has been written to the guest
2091              state of thread 'tid', offset 'guest_state_offset' length
2092              'size'.  We need to look at that return value and set the
2093              shadow return value accordingly.  The shadow return value
2094              required is handed to us "under the counter" through the
2095              global variable 'last_seg_added'.  This is all very ugly, not
2096              to mention, non-thread-safe should V ever become
2097              multithreaded. */
2098           /* assert the place where the return value is is a legit int reg */
2099           tl_assert(is_integer_guest_reg(guest_state_offset, size));
2100           /* Now we need to look at the returned value, to see whether the
2101              malloc succeeded or not. */
2102           p = get_guest_intreg(tid, 0/*non-shadow*/, guest_state_offset, size);
2103           if ((UWord)NULL == p) {
2104              // if alloc failed, eg. realloc on bogus pointer
2105              put_guest_intreg(tid, 1/*first-shadow*/,
2106                               guest_state_offset, size, (UWord)NONPTR );
2107           } else {
2108              // alloc didn't fail.  Check we have the correct segment.
2109              tl_assert(p == last_seg_added->addr);
2110              put_guest_intreg(tid, 1/*first-shadow*/,
2111                               guest_state_offset, size, (UWord)last_seg_added );
2112           }
2113        } 
2114        else if (f == (Addr)h_replace_free
2115                 || f == (Addr)h_replace___builtin_delete
2116                 || f == (Addr)h_replace___builtin_vec_delete
2117              // || f == (Addr)VG_(cli_block_size)
2118                 || f == (Addr)VG_(message))
2119        {
2120           // Probably best to set the (non-existent!) return value to
2121           // non-pointer.
2122           tl_assert(is_integer_guest_reg(guest_state_offset, size));
2123           put_guest_intreg(tid, 1/*first-shadow*/,
2124                            guest_state_offset, size, (UWord)NONPTR );
2125        }
2126        else {
2127           // Anything else, probably best to set return value to non-pointer.
2128           //VG_(set_thread_shadow_archreg)(tid, reg, (UInt)UNKNOWN);
2129           Char fbuf[100];
2130           VG_(printf)("f = %#lx\n", f);
2131           VG_(get_fnname)(f, fbuf, 100);
2132           VG_(printf)("name = %s\n", fbuf);
2133           VG_(tool_panic)("argh: clientcall");
2134        }
2135     }
2136

2173     /*--------------------------------------------------------------------*/
2174     /*--- System calls                                                 ---*/
2175     /*--------------------------------------------------------------------*/
2176     
2177     void h_pre_syscall ( ThreadId tid, UInt sysno,
2178                          UWord* args, UInt nArgs )
2179     {
2180        /* we don't do anything at the pre-syscall point */
2181     }
2182     
2183     /* The post-syscall table is a table of pairs (number, flag).
2184     
2185        'flag' is only ever zero or one.  If it is zero, it indicates that
2186        default handling for that syscall is required -- namely that the
2187        syscall is deemed to return NONPTR.  This is the case for the vast
2188        majority of syscalls.  If it is one then some special
2189        syscall-specific handling is is required.  No further details of it
2190        are stored in the table.
2191     
2192        On Linux and Darwin, 'number' is a __NR_xxx constant.
2193     
2194        On AIX5, 'number' is an Int*, which points to the Int variable
2195        holding the currently assigned number for this syscall.
2196     
2197        When querying the table, we compare the supplied syscall number
2198        with the 'number' field (directly on Linux and Darwin, after
2199        dereferencing on AIX5), to find the relevant entry.  This requires a
2200        linear search of the table.  To stop the costs getting too high, the
2201        table is incrementally rearranged after each search, to move commonly
2202        requested items a bit closer to the front.
2203     
2204        The table is built once, the first time it is used.  After that we
2205        merely query it (and reorder the entries as a result). */
2206     
2207     static XArray* /* of UWordPair */ post_syscall_table = NULL;
2208     
2209     static void setup_post_syscall_table ( void )
2210     {
2211        tl_assert(!post_syscall_table);
2212        post_syscall_table = VG_(newXA)( VG_(malloc), "pc.h_main.spst.1",
2213                                         VG_(free), sizeof(UWordPair) );
2214        tl_assert(post_syscall_table);
2215     
2216        /* --------------- LINUX --------------- */
2217     
2218     #  if defined(VGO_linux)
2219     
2220     #     define ADD(_flag, _syscallname) \
2221              do { UWordPair p; p.uw1 = (_syscallname); p.uw2 = (_flag); \
2222                   VG_(addToXA)( post_syscall_table, &p ); \
2223              } while (0)

2590     
2591     
2592     void h_post_syscall ( ThreadId tid, UInt sysno, 
2593                           UWord* args, UInt nArgs, SysRes res )
2594     {
2595        Word i, n;
2596        UWordPair* pair;
2597     
2598        if (!post_syscall_table)
2599           setup_post_syscall_table();
2600     
2601        /* search for 'sysno' in the post_syscall_table */
2602        n = VG_(sizeXA)( post_syscall_table );
2603        for (i = 0; i < n; i++) {
2604           pair = VG_(indexXA)( post_syscall_table, i );
2605     #     if defined(VGO_linux) || defined(VGO_darwin)
2606           if (pair->uw1 == (UWord)sysno)
2607              break;
2608     #     elif defined(VGO_aix5)
2609           if (*(Int*)(pair->uw1) == (Int)sysno)
2610              break;
2611     #     else
2612     #        error "Unsupported OS"
2613     #     endif
2614        }
2615     
2616        tl_assert(i >= 0 && i <= n);
2617     
2618        if (i == n) {
2619           VG_(printf)("sysno == %s", VG_SYSNUM_STRING_EXTRA(sysno));
2620           VG_(tool_panic)("unhandled syscall");
2621        }
2622     
2623        /* So we found the relevant entry.  Move it one step
2624           forward so as to speed future accesses to it. */
2625        if (i > 0) {
2626           UWordPair tmp, *p, *q;
2627           p = VG_(indexXA)( post_syscall_table, i-1 );
2628           q = VG_(indexXA)( post_syscall_table, i-0 );
2629           tmp = *p;
2630           *p = *q;
2631           *q = tmp;
2632           i--;
2633        }
2634     
2635        /* Deal with the common case */
2636        pair = VG_(indexXA)( post_syscall_table, i );
2637        if (pair->uw2 == 0)
2638           /* the common case */
2639           goto res_NONPTR_err_NONPTR;
2640     
2641        /* Special handling for all remaining cases */
2642        tl_assert(pair->uw2 == 1);
2643     
2644     #  if defined(__NR_arch_prctl)
2645        if (sysno == __NR_arch_prctl) {
2646           /* This is nasty.  On amd64-linux, arch_prctl may write a
2647              value to guest_FS_ZERO, and we need to shadow that value.
2648              Hence apply nonptr_or_unknown to it here, after the
2649              syscall completes. */
2650           post_reg_write_nonptr_or_unknown( tid, PC_OFF_FS_ZERO, 
2651                                                  PC_SZB_FS_ZERO );
2652           goto res_NONPTR_err_NONPTR;
2653        }
2654     #  endif
2655     
2656     #  if defined(__NR_brk)
2657        // With brk(), result (of kernel syscall, not glibc wrapper) is a heap
2658        // pointer.  Make the shadow UNKNOWN.
2659        if (sysno == __NR_brk)
2660           goto res_UNKNOWN_err_NONPTR;
2661     #  endif
2662     
2663        // With mmap, new_mem_mmap() has already been called and added the
2664        // segment (we did it there because we had the result address and size
2665        // handy).  So just set the return value shadow.
2666        if (sysno == __NR_mmap
2667     #      if defined(__NR_mmap2)
2668            || sysno == __NR_mmap2
2669     #      endif
2670     #      if defined(__NR_AIX5___loadx)
2671            || (sysno == __NR_AIX5___loadx && __NR_AIX5___loadx != __NR_AIX5_UNKNOWN)
2672     #      endif
2673     #      if defined(__NR_AIX5_kload)
2674            || (sysno == __NR_AIX5_kload && __NR_AIX5_kload != __NR_AIX5_UNKNOWN)
2675     #      endif
2676           ) {
2677           if (sr_isError(res)) {
2678              // mmap() had an error, return value is a small negative integer
2679              goto res_NONPTR_err_NONPTR;
2680           } else {
2681              goto res_UNKNOWN_err_NONPTR;
2682           }
2683           return;
2684        }
2685     
2686        // shmat uses the same scheme.  We will just have had a
2687        // notification via new_mem_mmap.  Just set the return value shadow.
2688     #  if defined(__NR_shmat)
2689        if (sysno == __NR_shmat) {
2690           if (sr_isError(res)) {
2691              goto res_NONPTR_err_NONPTR;
2692           } else {
2693              goto res_UNKNOWN_err_NONPTR;
2694           }
2695        }
2696     #  endif
2697     
2698     #  if defined(__NR_shmget)
2699        if (sysno == __NR_shmget)
2700           // FIXME: is this correct?
2701           goto res_UNKNOWN_err_NONPTR;
2702     #  endif
2703     
2704     #  if defined(__NR_ipc) && defined(VKI_SHMAT)
2705        /* perhaps this should be further conditionalised with
2706           && (defined(VGP_ppc32_linux) || defined(VGP_ppc64_linux)
2707           Note, this just copies the behaviour of __NR_shmget above.
2708     
2709           JRS 2009 June 02: it seems that the return value from
2710           sys_ipc(VKI_SHMAT, ...) doesn't have much relationship to the
2711           result returned by the originating user-level shmat call.  It's
2712           different (and much lower) by a large but integral number of
2713           pages.  I don't have time to chase this right now.  Observed on
2714           ppc{32,64}-linux.  Result appears to be false errors from apps
2715           using shmat.  Confusion though -- shouldn't be related to the
2716           actual numeric values returned by the syscall, though, should
2717           it?  Confused.  Maybe some bad interaction with a
2718           nonpointer-or-unknown heuristic? */
2719        if (sysno == __NR_ipc) {
2720           if (args[0] == VKI_SHMAT) {
2721              goto res_UNKNOWN_err_NONPTR;
2722           } else {
2723              goto res_NONPTR_err_NONPTR;
2724           }
2725        }
2726     #  endif
2727     
2728        /* If we get here, it implies the corresponding entry in
2729           post_syscall_table has .w2 == 1, which in turn implies there
2730           should be special-case code for it above. */
2731        tl_assert(0);
2732     
2733       res_NONPTR_err_NONPTR:
2734        VG_(set_syscall_return_shadows)( tid, /* retval */ (UWord)NONPTR, 0,
2735                                              /* error */  (UWord)NONPTR, 0 );
2736        return;
2737     
2738       res_UNKNOWN_err_NONPTR:
2739        VG_(set_syscall_return_shadows)( tid, /* retval */ (UWord)UNKNOWN, 0,
2740                                              /* error */  (UWord)NONPTR, 0 );
2741        return;
2742     }
2743     
2744     
2745     /*--------------------------------------------------------------------*/
2746     /*--- Functions called from generated code                         ---*/
2747     /*--------------------------------------------------------------------*/
