2749     #if SC_SEGS
2750     static void checkSeg ( Seg vseg ) {
2751        tl_assert(vseg == UNKNOWN || vseg == NONPTR || vseg == BOTTOM
2752                  || Seg__plausible(vseg) );
2753     }
2754     #endif
2755     
2756     // XXX: could be more sophisticated -- actually track the lowest/highest
2757     // valid address used by the program, and then return False for anything
2758     // below that (using a suitable safety margin).  Also, nothing above
2759     // 0xc0000000 is valid [unless you've changed that in your kernel]
2760     static inline Bool looks_like_a_pointer(Addr a)
2761     {
2762     #  if defined(VGA_x86) || defined(VGA_ppc32)
2763        tl_assert(sizeof(UWord) == 4);
2764        return (a > 0x800000UL && a < 0xFF000000UL);
2765     
2766     #  elif defined(VGA_amd64) || defined(VGA_ppc64)
2767        tl_assert(sizeof(UWord) == 8);
2768        return (a >= 16 * 0x10000UL && a < 0xFF00000000000000UL);
2769     
2770     #  elif defined(VGA_arm)
2771        /* Unfortunately arm-linux seems to load the exe at very low, at
2772           0x8000, so we have to assume any value above that is a pointer,
2773           which is pretty dismal. */
2774        tl_assert(sizeof(UWord) == 4);
2775        return (a >= 0x00008000UL && a < 0xFF000000UL);
2776     
2777     #  elif defined(VGA_s390x)
2778        tl_assert(0);
2779     #  else
2780     #    error "Unsupported architecture"
2781     #  endif
2782     }
2783     
2784     static inline VG_REGPARM(1)
2785     Seg* nonptr_or_unknown(UWord x)
2786     {
2787        Seg* res = looks_like_a_pointer(x) ? UNKNOWN : NONPTR;
2788        if (0) VG_(printf)("nonptr_or_unknown %s %#lx\n", 
2789                           res==UNKNOWN ? "UUU" : "nnn", x);
2790        return res;
2791     }

2851     // This function is called *a lot*; inlining it sped up Konqueror by 20%.
2852     static inline
2853     void check_load_or_store(Bool is_write, Addr m, UWord sz, Seg* mptr_vseg)
2854     {
2855     #if 0
2856        tl_assert(0);
2857        if (h_clo_lossage_check) {
2858           Seg* seg;
2859           stats__tot_mem_refs++;
2860           if (ISList__findI0( seglist, (Addr)m, &seg )) {
2861              /* m falls inside 'seg' (that is, we are making a memory
2862                 reference inside 'seg').  Now, really mptr_vseg should be
2863                 a tracked segment of some description.  Badness is when
2864                 mptr_vseg is UNKNOWN, BOTTOM or NONPTR at this point,
2865                 since that means we've lost the type of it somehow: it
2866                 shoud say that m points into a real segment (preferable
2867                 'seg'), but it doesn't. */
2868              if (Seg__status_is_SegHeap(seg)) {
2869                 stats__refs_in_a_seg++;
2870                 if (UNKNOWN == mptr_vseg
2871                     || BOTTOM == mptr_vseg || NONPTR == mptr_vseg) {
2872                    ExeContext* ec;
2873                    Char buf[100];
2874                    static UWord xx = 0;
2875                    stats__refs_lost_seg++;
2876                    ec = VG_(record_ExeContext)( VG_(get_running_tid)(), 0 );
2877                    inc_lossage(ec);
2878                    if (0) {
2879                       VG_(message)(Vg_DebugMsg, "");
2880                       VG_(message)(Vg_DebugMsg,
2881                                    "Lossage %s %#lx sz %lu inside block alloc'd",
2882                                    is_write ? "wr" : "rd", m, (UWord)sz);
2883                       VG_(pp_ExeContext)(Seg__where(seg));
2884                    }
2885                    if (xx++ < 0) {
2886                       Addr ip = VG_(get_IP)( VG_(get_running_tid)() );
2887                       (void)VG_(describe_IP)( ip, buf, sizeof(buf)-1);
2888                       buf[sizeof(buf)-1] = 0;
2889                       VG_(printf)("lossage at %p %s\n", ec, buf );
2890                    }
2891                 }
2892              }
2893           }
2894        } /* clo_lossage_check */
2895     #endif
2896     
2897     #  if SC_SEGS
2898        checkSeg(mptr_vseg);
2899     #  endif
2900     
2901        if (UNKNOWN == mptr_vseg) {
2902           // do nothing
2903     
2904        } else if (BOTTOM == mptr_vseg) {
2905           // do nothing
2906     
2907        } else if (NONPTR == mptr_vseg) {
2908           h_record_heap_error( m, sz, mptr_vseg, is_write );
2909     
2910        } else {
2911           // check all segment ranges in the circle
2912           // if none match, warn about 1st seg
2913           // else,          check matching one isn't freed
2914           Bool is_ok = False;
2915           Seg* curr  = mptr_vseg;
2916           Addr mhi;
2917     
2918           // Accesses partly outside range are an error, unless it's an aligned
2919           // word-sized read, and --partial-loads-ok=yes.  This is to cope with
2920           // gcc's/glibc's habits of doing word-sized accesses that read past
2921           // the ends of arrays/strings.
2922           // JRS 2008-sept-11: couldn't this be moved off the critical path?
2923           if (!is_write && sz == sizeof(UWord)
2924               && h_clo_partial_loads_ok && SHMEM_IS_WORD_ALIGNED(m)) {
2925              mhi = m;
2926           } else {
2927              mhi = m+sz-1;
2928           }
2929     
2930           if (0) VG_(printf)("calling seg_ci %p %#lx %#lx\n", curr,m,mhi);
2931           is_ok = curr->addr <= m && mhi < curr->addr + curr->szB;
2932     
2933           // If it's an overrun/underrun of a freed block, don't give both
2934           // warnings, since the first one mentions that the block has been
2935           // freed.
2936           if ( ! is_ok || Seg__is_freed(curr) )
2937              h_record_heap_error( m, sz, mptr_vseg, is_write );
2938        }
2939     }

2941     // ------------------ Load handlers ------------------ //
2942     
2943     /* On 32 bit targets, we will use:
2944           check_load1 check_load2 check_load4_P
2945           check_load4  (for 32-bit FP reads)
2946           check_load8  (for 64-bit FP reads)
2947           check_load16 (for xmm/altivec reads)
2948        On 64 bit targets, we will use:
2949           check_load1 check_load2 check_load4 check_load8_P
2950           check_load8  (for 64-bit FP reads)
2951           check_load16 (for xmm/altivec reads)
2952     
2953        A "_P" handler reads a pointer from memory, and so returns a value
2954        to the generated code -- the pointer's shadow value.  That implies
2955        that check_load4_P is only to be called on a 32 bit host and
2956        check_load8_P is only to be called on a 64 bit host.  For all other
2957        cases no shadow value is returned; we merely check that the pointer
2958        (m) matches the block described by its shadow value (mptr_vseg).
2959     */
2960     
2961     // This handles 128 bit loads on both 32 bit and 64 bit targets.
2962     static VG_REGPARM(2)
2963     void check_load16(Addr m, Seg* mptr_vseg)
2964     {
2965     #  if SC_SEGS
2966        checkSeg(mptr_vseg);
2967     #  endif
2968        check_load_or_store(/*is_write*/False, m, 16, mptr_vseg);
2969     }
2970     
2971     // This handles 64 bit FP-or-otherwise-nonpointer loads on both
2972     // 32 bit and 64 bit targets.
2973     static VG_REGPARM(2)
2974     void check_load8(Addr m, Seg* mptr_vseg)
2975     {
2976     #  if SC_SEGS
2977        checkSeg(mptr_vseg);
2978     #  endif
2979        check_load_or_store(/*is_write*/False, m, 8, mptr_vseg);
2980     }
2981     
2982     // This handles 64 bit loads on 64 bit targets.  It must
2983     // not be called on 32 bit targets.
2984     // return m.vseg
2985     static VG_REGPARM(2)
2986     Seg* check_load8_P(Addr m, Seg* mptr_vseg)
2987     {
2988        Seg* vseg;
2989        tl_assert(sizeof(UWord) == 8); /* DO NOT REMOVE */
2990     #  if SC_SEGS
2991        checkSeg(mptr_vseg);
2992     #  endif
2993        check_load_or_store(/*is_write*/False, m, 8, mptr_vseg);
2994        if (VG_IS_8_ALIGNED(m)) {
2995           vseg = get_mem_vseg(m);
2996        } else {
2997           vseg = nonptr_or_unknown( *(ULong*)m );
2998        }
2999        return vseg;
3000     }
3001     
3002     // This handles 32 bit loads on 32 bit targets.  It must
3003     // not be called on 64 bit targets.
3004     // return m.vseg
3005     static VG_REGPARM(2)
3006     Seg* check_load4_P(Addr m, Seg* mptr_vseg)
3007     {
3008        Seg* vseg;
3009        tl_assert(sizeof(UWord) == 4); /* DO NOT REMOVE */
3010     #  if SC_SEGS
3011        checkSeg(mptr_vseg);
3012     #  endif
3013        check_load_or_store(/*is_write*/False, m, 4, mptr_vseg);
3014        if (VG_IS_4_ALIGNED(m)) {
3015           vseg = get_mem_vseg(m);
3016        } else {
3017           vseg = nonptr_or_unknown( *(UInt*)m );
3018        }
3019        return vseg;
3020     }

3024     void check_load4(Addr m, Seg* mptr_vseg)
3025     {
3026     #  if SC_SEGS
3027        checkSeg(mptr_vseg);
3028     #  endif
3029        check_load_or_store(/*is_write*/False, m, 4, mptr_vseg);
3030     }

3039        check_load_or_store(/*is_write*/False, m, 2, mptr_vseg);

3043     static VG_REGPARM(2)
3044     void check_load1(Addr m, Seg* mptr_vseg)
3045     {

3052     // ------------------ Store handlers ------------------ //
3053     
3054     /* On 32 bit targets, we will use:
3055           check_store1 check_store2 check_store4_P check_store4C_P
3056           check_store4 (for 32-bit nonpointer stores)
3057           check_store8_ms4B_ls4B (for 64-bit stores)
3058           check_store16_ms4B_4B_4B_ls4B (for xmm/altivec stores)
3059     
3060        On 64 bit targets, we will use:
3061           check_store1 check_store2 check_store4 check_store4C
3062           check_store8_P check_store_8C_P
3063           check_store8_all8B (for 64-bit nonpointer stores)
3064           check_store16_ms8B_ls8B (for xmm/altivec stores)
3065     
3066        A "_P" handler writes a pointer to memory, and so has an extra
3067        argument -- the pointer's shadow value.  That implies that
3068        check_store4{,C}_P is only to be called on a 32 bit host and
3069        check_store8{,C}_P is only to be called on a 64 bit host.  For all
3070        other cases, and for the misaligned _P cases, the strategy is to
3071        let the store go through, and then snoop around with
3072        nonptr_or_unknown to fix up the shadow values of any affected
3073        words. */
3074     
3075     /* Helpers for store-conditionals.  Ugly kludge :-(
3076        They all return 1 if the SC was successful and 0 if it failed. */
3077     static inline UWord do_store_conditional_32( Addr m/*dst*/, UInt t/*val*/ )
3078     {
3079     #  if defined(VGA_ppc32) || defined(VGA_ppc64)
3080        UWord success;
3081        /* If this assertion fails, the underlying IR is (semantically) ill-formed
3082           as per the IR spec for IRStmt_Store. */
3083        tl_assert(VG_IS_4_ALIGNED(m));
3084        __asm__ __volatile__(
3085           "stwcx. %2,0,%1"    "\n\t" /* data,0,addr */
3086           "mfcr   %0"         "\n\t"
3087           "srwi   %0,%0,29"   "\n\t" /* move relevant CR bit to LSB */
3088           : /*out*/"=b"(success) 
3089           : /*in*/ "b"(m), "b"( (UWord)t ) 
3090           : /*trash*/ "memory", "cc"
3091             /* Note: srwi is OK even on 64-bit host because the we're
3092                after bit 29 (normal numbering) and we mask off all the
3093                other junk just below. */
3094        );
3095        return success & (UWord)1;
3096     #  else
3097        tl_assert(0); /* not implemented on other platforms */
3098     #  endif
3099     }
3100     
3101     static inline UWord do_store_conditional_64( Addr m/*dst*/, ULong t/*val*/ )
3102     {
3103     #  if defined(VGA_ppc64)
3104        UWord success;
3105        /* If this assertion fails, the underlying IR is (semantically) ill-formed
3106           as per the IR spec for IRStmt_Store. */
3107        tl_assert(VG_IS_8_ALIGNED(m));
3108        __asm__ __volatile__(
3109           "stdcx. %2,0,%1"    "\n\t" /* data,0,addr */
3110           "mfcr   %0"         "\n\t"
3111           "srdi   %0,%0,29"   "\n\t" /* move relevant CR bit to LSB */
3112           : /*out*/"=b"(success) 
3113           : /*in*/ "b"(m), "b"( (UWord)t ) 
3114           : /*trash*/ "memory", "cc"
3115        );
3116        return success & (UWord)1;
3117     #  else
3118        tl_assert(0); /* not implemented on other platforms */
3119     #  endif
3120     }
3121     
3122     /* Apply nonptr_or_unknown to all the words intersecting
3123        [a, a+len). */
3124     static inline VG_REGPARM(2)
3125     void nonptr_or_unknown_range ( Addr a, SizeT len )
3126     {
3127        const SizeT wszB = sizeof(UWord);
3128        Addr wfirst = VG_ROUNDDN(a,       wszB);
3129        Addr wlast  = VG_ROUNDDN(a+len-1, wszB);
3130        Addr a2;
3131        tl_assert(wfirst <= wlast);
3132        for (a2 = wfirst ; a2 <= wlast; a2 += wszB) {
3133           set_mem_vseg( a2, nonptr_or_unknown( *(UWord*)a2 ));
3134        }
3135     }
3136     
3137     // Write to shadow memory, for a 32-bit store.  Must only
3138     // be used on 32-bit targets.
3139     static inline VG_REGPARM(2)
3140     void do_shadow_store4_P( Addr m, Seg* vseg )
3141     {
3142        tl_assert(sizeof(UWord) == 4); /* DO NOT REMOVE */
3143        if (VG_IS_4_ALIGNED(m)) {
3144           set_mem_vseg( m, vseg );
3145        } else {
3146           // straddling two words
3147           nonptr_or_unknown_range(m, 4);
3148        }
3149     }
3150     
3151     // Write to shadow memory, for a 64-bit store.  Must only
3152     // be used on 64-bit targets.
3153     static inline VG_REGPARM(2)
3154     void do_shadow_store8_P( Addr m, Seg* vseg )
3155     {
3156        tl_assert(sizeof(UWord) == 8); /* DO NOT REMOVE */
3157        if (VG_IS_8_ALIGNED(m)) {
3158           set_mem_vseg( m, vseg );
3159        } else {
3160           // straddling two words
3161           nonptr_or_unknown_range(m, 8);
3162        }
3163     }
3164     
3165     // This handles 128 bit stores on 64 bit targets.  The
3166     // store data is passed in 2 pieces, the most significant
3167     // bits first.
3168     static VG_REGPARM(3)
3169     void check_store16_ms8B_ls8B(Addr m, Seg* mptr_vseg,
3170                                  UWord ms8B, UWord ls8B)
3171     {
3172        tl_assert(sizeof(UWord) == 8); /* DO NOT REMOVE */
3173     #  if SC_SEGS
3174        checkSeg(mptr_vseg);
3175     #  endif
3176        check_load_or_store(/*is_write*/True, m, 16, mptr_vseg);
3177        // Actually *do* the STORE here
3178        if (host_is_little_endian()) {
3179           // FIXME: aren't we really concerned whether the guest
3180           // is little endian, not whether the host is?
3181           *(ULong*)(m + 0) = ls8B;
3182           *(ULong*)(m + 8) = ms8B;
3183        } else {
3184           *(ULong*)(m + 0) = ms8B;
3185           *(ULong*)(m + 8) = ls8B;
3186        }
3187        nonptr_or_unknown_range(m, 16);
3188     }
3189     
3190     // This handles 128 bit stores on 64 bit targets.  The
3191     // store data is passed in 2 pieces, the most significant
3192     // bits first.
3193     static VG_REGPARM(3)
3194     void check_store16_ms4B_4B_4B_ls4B(Addr m, Seg* mptr_vseg,
3195                                        UWord ms4B, UWord w2,
3196                                        UWord w1,   UWord ls4B)
3197     {
3198        tl_assert(sizeof(UWord) == 4); /* DO NOT REMOVE */
3199     #  if SC_SEGS
3200        checkSeg(mptr_vseg);
3201     #  endif
3202        check_load_or_store(/*is_write*/True, m, 16, mptr_vseg);
3203        // Actually *do* the STORE here
3204        if (host_is_little_endian()) {
3205           // FIXME: aren't we really concerned whether the guest
3206           // is little endian, not whether the host is?
3207           *(UInt*)(m +  0) = ls4B;
3208           *(UInt*)(m +  4) = w1;
3209           *(UInt*)(m +  8) = w2;
3210           *(UInt*)(m + 12) = ms4B;
3211        } else {
3212           *(UInt*)(m +  0) = ms4B;
3213           *(UInt*)(m +  4) = w2;
3214           *(UInt*)(m +  8) = w1;
3215           *(UInt*)(m + 12) = ls4B;
3216        }
3217        nonptr_or_unknown_range(m, 16);
3218     }
3219     
3220     // This handles 64 bit stores on 32 bit targets.  The
3221     // store data is passed in 2 pieces, the most significant
3222     // bits first.
3223     static VG_REGPARM(3)
3224     void check_store8_ms4B_ls4B(Addr m, Seg* mptr_vseg,
3225                                 UWord ms4B, UWord ls4B)
3226     {
3227        tl_assert(sizeof(UWord) == 4); /* DO NOT REMOVE */
3228     #  if SC_SEGS
3229        checkSeg(mptr_vseg);
3230     #  endif
3231        check_load_or_store(/*is_write*/True, m, 8, mptr_vseg);
3232        // Actually *do* the STORE here
3233        if (host_is_little_endian()) {
3234           // FIXME: aren't we really concerned whether the guest
3235           // is little endian, not whether the host is?
3236           *(UInt*)(m + 0) = ls4B;
3237           *(UInt*)(m + 4) = ms4B;
3238        } else {
3239           *(UInt*)(m + 0) = ms4B;
3240           *(UInt*)(m + 4) = ls4B;
3241        }

3243     }

3245     // This handles 64 bit non pointer stores on 64 bit targets.
3246     // It must not be called on 32 bit targets.

3253     #  endif

3255        // Actually *do* the STORE here

3258     }

3260     // This handles 64 bit stores on 64 bit targets.  It must
3261     // not be called on 32 bit targets.
3262     static VG_REGPARM(3)
3263     void check_store8_P(Addr m, Seg* mptr_vseg, UWord t, Seg* t_vseg)
3264     {
3265        tl_assert(sizeof(UWord) == 8); /* DO NOT REMOVE */
3266     #  if SC_SEGS

3268        checkSeg(mptr_vseg);
3269     #  endif
3270        check_load_or_store(/*is_write*/True, m, 8, mptr_vseg);
3271        // Actually *do* the STORE here
3272        *(ULong*)m = t;
3273        do_shadow_store8_P( m, t_vseg );
3274     }

3276     // This handles 64 bit store-conditionals on 64 bit targets.  It must
3277     // not be called on 32 bit targets.
3278     static VG_REGPARM(3)
3279     UWord check_store8C_P(Addr m, Seg* mptr_vseg, UWord t, Seg* t_vseg)
3280     {
3281        UWord success;
3282        tl_assert(sizeof(UWord) == 8); /* DO NOT REMOVE */
3283     #  if SC_SEGS

3285        checkSeg(mptr_vseg);
3286     #  endif

3291           do_shadow_store8_P( m, t_vseg );

3387     
3388     // Nb: if the result is BOTTOM, return immedately -- don't let BOTTOM
3389     //     be changed to NONPTR by a range check on the result.
3390     #define BINOP(bt, nn, nu, np, un, uu, up, pn, pu, pp) \
3391        if (BOTTOM == seg1 || BOTTOM == seg2) { bt;                   \
3392        } else if (NONPTR == seg1)  { if      (NONPTR == seg2)  { nn; }  \
3393                                      else if (UNKNOWN == seg2) { nu; }    \
3394                                      else                      { np; }    \
3395        } else if (UNKNOWN == seg1) { if      (NONPTR == seg2)  { un; }    \
3396                                      else if (UNKNOWN == seg2) { uu; }    \
3397                                      else                      { up; }    \
3398        } else                      { if      (NONPTR == seg2)  { pn; }    \
3399                                      else if (UNKNOWN == seg2) { pu; }    \
3400                                      else                      { pp; }    \
3401        }
3402     
3403     #define BINERROR(opname)                    \
3404        h_record_arith_error(seg1, seg2, opname);  \
3405        out = NONPTR
3406     
3407     
3408     // -------------
3409     //  + | n  ?  p
3410     // -------------
3411     //  n | n  ?  p
3412     //  ? | ?  ?  ?
3413     //  p | p  ?  e   (all results become n if they look like a non-pointer)
3414     // -------------
3415     static Seg* do_addW_result(Seg* seg1, Seg* seg2, UWord result, HChar* opname)
3416     {
3417        Seg* out;
3418     #  if SC_SEGS
3419        checkSeg(seg1);
3420        checkSeg(seg2);
3421     #  endif
3422        BINOP(
3423           return BOTTOM,
3424           out = NONPTR,  out = UNKNOWN, out = seg2,
3425           out = UNKNOWN, out = UNKNOWN, out = UNKNOWN,
3426           out = seg1,    out = UNKNOWN,       BINERROR(opname)
3427        );
3428        return ( looks_like_a_pointer(result) ? out : NONPTR );
3429     }
3430     
3431     static VG_REGPARM(3) Seg* do_addW(Seg* seg1, Seg* seg2, UWord result)
3432     {
3433        Seg* out;
3434     #  if SC_SEGS
3435        checkSeg(seg1);
3436        checkSeg(seg2);
3437     #  endif
3438        out = do_addW_result(seg1, seg2, result, "Add32/Add64");
3439     #  if SC_SEGS
3440        checkSeg(out);
3441     #  endif
3442        return out;
3443     }
3444     
3445     // -------------
3446     //  - | n  ?  p      (Nb: operation is seg1 - seg2)
3447     // -------------
3448     //  n | n  ?  n+     (+) happens a lot due to "cmp", but result should never
3449     //  ? | ?  ?  n/B        be used, so give 'n'
3450     //  p | p  p? n*/B   (*) and possibly link the segments
3451     // -------------
3452     static VG_REGPARM(3) Seg* do_subW(Seg* seg1, Seg* seg2, UWord result)
3453     {
3454        Seg* out;
3455     #  if SC_SEGS
3456        checkSeg(seg1);
3457        checkSeg(seg2);
3458     #  endif
3459        // Nb: when returning BOTTOM, don't let it go through the range-check;
3460        //     a segment linking offset can easily look like a nonptr.
3461        BINOP(
3462           return BOTTOM,
3463           out = NONPTR,  out = UNKNOWN,    out = NONPTR,
3464           out = UNKNOWN, out = UNKNOWN,    return BOTTOM,
3465           out = seg1,    out = seg1/*??*/, return BOTTOM
3466        );
3467        #if 0
3468              // This is for the p-p segment-linking case
3469              Seg end2 = seg2;
3470              while (end2->links != seg2) end2 = end2->links;
3471              end2->links = seg1->links;
3472              seg1->links = seg2;
3473              return NONPTR;
3474        #endif
3475        return ( looks_like_a_pointer(result) ? out : NONPTR );
3476     }
3477     
3478     // -------------
3479     //  & | n  ?  p
3480     // -------------
3481     //  n | n  ?  p
3482     //  ? | ?  ?  ?
3483     //  p | p  ?  *  (*) if p1==p2 then p else e (see comment)
3484     // -------------
3485     /* Seems to be OK to And two pointers:
3486          testq %ptr1,%ptr2
3487          jnz ..
3488        which possibly derives from
3489          if (ptr1 & ptr2) { A } else { B }
3490        not sure what that means
3491     */
3492     static VG_REGPARM(3) Seg* do_andW(Seg* seg1, Seg* seg2, 
3493                                       UWord result, UWord args_diff)
3494     {
3495        Seg* out;
3496        if (0 == args_diff) {
3497           // p1==p2
3498           out = seg1;
3499        } else {
3500           BINOP(
3501              return BOTTOM,
3502              out = NONPTR,  out = UNKNOWN, out = seg2,
3503              out = UNKNOWN, out = UNKNOWN, out = UNKNOWN,
3504              out = seg1,    out = UNKNOWN, out = NONPTR
3505                                            /*BINERROR("And32/And64")*/
3506           );
3507        }
3508        out = ( looks_like_a_pointer(result) ? out : NONPTR );
3509        return out;
3510     }
3511     
3512     // -------------
3513     // `|`| n  ?  p
3514     // -------------
3515     //  n | n  ?  p
3516     //  ? | ?  ?  ?
3517     //  p | p  ?  n
3518     // -------------
3519     /* It's OK to Or two pointers together, but the result definitely
3520        isn't a pointer.  Why would you want to do that?  Because of this:
3521          char* p1 = malloc(..);
3522          char* p2 = malloc(..);
3523          ...
3524          if (p1 || p2) { .. }
3525        In this case gcc on x86/amd64 quite literally or-s the two pointers
3526        together and throws away the result, the purpose of which is merely
3527        to sets %eflags.Z/%rflags.Z.  So we have to allow it.
3528     */
3529     static VG_REGPARM(3) Seg* do_orW(Seg* seg1, Seg* seg2, UWord result)
3530     {
3531        Seg* out;
3532        BINOP(
3533           return BOTTOM,
3534           out = NONPTR,  out = UNKNOWN, out = seg2,
3535           out = UNKNOWN, out = UNKNOWN, out = UNKNOWN,
3536           out = seg1,    out = UNKNOWN, out = NONPTR
3537        );
3538        out = ( looks_like_a_pointer(result) ? out : NONPTR );
3539        return out;
3540     }
3541     
3542     // -------------
3543     //  ~ | n  ?  p
3544     // -------------
3545     //    | n  n  n
3546     // -------------
3547     static VG_REGPARM(2) Seg* do_notW(Seg* seg1, UWord result)
3548     {
3549     #  if SC_SEGS
3550        checkSeg(seg1);
3551     #  endif
3552        if (BOTTOM == seg1) return BOTTOM;
3553        return NONPTR;
3554     }
3555     
3556     // Pointers are rarely multiplied, but sometimes legitimately, eg. as hash
3557     // function inputs.  But two pointers args --> error.
3558     // Pretend it always returns a nonptr.  Maybe improve later.
3559     static VG_REGPARM(2) Seg* do_mulW(Seg* seg1, Seg* seg2)
3560     {
3561     #  if SC_SEGS
3562        checkSeg(seg1);
3563        checkSeg(seg2);
3564     #  endif
3565        if (is_known_segment(seg1) && is_known_segment(seg2))
3566           h_record_arith_error(seg1, seg2, "Mul32/Mul64");
3567        return NONPTR;
3568     }
3569     
3570      
3571     /*--------------------------------------------------------------------*/
3572     /*--- Instrumentation                                              ---*/
3573     /*--------------------------------------------------------------------*/
3574     
3575     /* The h_ instrumenter that follows is complex, since it deals with
3576        shadow value computation.
3577     
3578        It also needs to generate instrumentation for the sg_ side of
3579        things.  That's relatively straightforward.  However, rather than
3580        confuse the code herein any further, we simply delegate the problem
3581        to sg_main.c, by using the four functions
3582        sg_instrument_{init,fini,IRStmt,final_jump}.  These four completely
3583        abstractify the sg_ instrumentation.  See comments in sg_main.c's
3584        instrumentation section for further details. */
3585     
3586     
3587     /* Carries info about a particular tmp.  The tmp's number is not
3588        recorded, as this is implied by (equal to) its index in the tmpMap
3589        in PCEnv.  The tmp's type is also not recorded, as this is present
3590        in PCEnv.sb->tyenv.
3591     
3592        When .kind is NonShad, .shadow may give the identity of the temp
3593        currently holding the associated shadow value, or it may be
3594        IRTemp_INVALID if code to compute the shadow has not yet been
3595        emitted.
3596     
3597        When .kind is Shad tmp holds a shadow value, and so .shadow must be
3598        IRTemp_INVALID, since it is illogical for a shadow tmp itself to be
3599        shadowed.
3600     */
3601     typedef
3602        enum { NonShad=1, Shad=2 }
3603        TempKind;
3604     
3605     typedef
3606        struct {
3607           TempKind kind;
3608           IRTemp   shadow;
3609        }
3610        TempMapEnt;
3611     
3612     
3613     
3614     /* Carries around state during Ptrcheck instrumentation. */
3615     typedef
3616        struct {
3617           /* MODIFIED: the superblock being constructed.  IRStmts are
3618              added. */
3619           IRSB* sb;
3620           Bool  trace;
3621     
3622           /* MODIFIED: a table [0 .. #temps_in_sb-1] which gives the
3623              current kind and possibly shadow temps for each temp in the
3624              IRSB being constructed.  Note that it does not contain the
3625              type of each tmp.  If you want to know the type, look at the
3626              relevant entry in sb->tyenv.  It follows that at all times
3627              during the instrumentation process, the valid indices for
3628              tmpMap and sb->tyenv are identical, being 0 .. N-1 where N is
3629              total number of NonShad and Shad temps allocated so far.
3630     
3631              The reason for this strange split (types in one place, all
3632              other info in another) is that we need the types to be
3633              attached to sb so as to make it possible to do
3634              "typeOfIRExpr(mce->bb->tyenv, ...)" at various places in the
3635              instrumentation process.
3636     
3637              Note that only integer temps of the guest word size are
3638              shadowed, since it is impossible (or meaningless) to hold a
3639              pointer in any other type of temp. */
3640           XArray* /* of TempMapEnt */ qmpMap;
3641     
3642           /* READONLY: the host word type.  Needed for constructing
3643              arguments of type 'HWord' to be passed to helper functions.
3644              Ity_I32 or Ity_I64 only. */
3645           IRType hWordTy;
3646     
3647           /* READONLY: the guest word type, Ity_I32 or Ity_I64 only. */
3648           IRType gWordTy;
3649     
3650           /* READONLY: the guest state size, so we can generate shadow
3651              offsets correctly. */
3652           Int guest_state_sizeB;
3653        }
3654        PCEnv;
3655     
3656     /* SHADOW TMP MANAGEMENT.  Shadow tmps are allocated lazily (on
3657        demand), as they are encountered.  This is for two reasons.
3658     
3659        (1) (less important reason): Many original tmps are unused due to
3660        initial IR optimisation, and we do not want to spaces in tables
3661        tracking them.
3662     
3663        Shadow IRTemps are therefore allocated on demand.  pce.tmpMap is a
3664        table indexed [0 .. n_types-1], which gives the current shadow for
3665        each original tmp, or INVALID_IRTEMP if none is so far assigned.
3666        It is necessary to support making multiple assignments to a shadow
3667        -- specifically, after testing a shadow for definedness, it needs
3668        to be made defined.  But IR's SSA property disallows this.
3669     
3670        (2) (more important reason): Therefore, when a shadow needs to get
3671        a new value, a new temporary is created, the value is assigned to
3672        that, and the tmpMap is updated to reflect the new binding.
3673     
3674        A corollary is that if the tmpMap maps a given tmp to
3675        IRTemp_INVALID and we are hoping to read that shadow tmp, it means
3676        there's a read-before-write error in the original tmps.  The IR
3677        sanity checker should catch all such anomalies, however.
3678     */
3679     
3680     /* Create a new IRTemp of type 'ty' and kind 'kind', and add it to
3681        both the table in pce->sb and to our auxiliary mapping.  Note that
3682        newTemp may cause pce->tmpMap to resize, hence previous results
3683        from VG_(indexXA)(pce->tmpMap) are invalidated. */
3684     static IRTemp newTemp ( PCEnv* pce, IRType ty, TempKind kind )
3685     {
3686        Word       newIx;
3687        TempMapEnt ent;
3688        IRTemp     tmp = newIRTemp(pce->sb->tyenv, ty);
3689        ent.kind   = kind;
3690        ent.shadow = IRTemp_INVALID;
3691        newIx = VG_(addToXA)( pce->qmpMap, &ent );
3692        tl_assert(newIx == (Word)tmp);
3693        return tmp;
3694     }
3695     
3696     /* Find the tmp currently shadowing the given original tmp.  If none
3697        so far exists, allocate one.  */
3698     static IRTemp findShadowTmp ( PCEnv* pce, IRTemp orig )
3699     {
3700        TempMapEnt* ent;
3701        /* VG_(indexXA) range-checks 'orig', hence no need to check
3702           here. */
3703        ent = (TempMapEnt*)VG_(indexXA)( pce->qmpMap, (Word)orig );
3704        tl_assert(ent->kind == NonShad);
3705        if (ent->shadow == IRTemp_INVALID) {
3706           IRTemp shadow = newTemp( pce, pce->gWordTy, Shad );
3707           /* newTemp may cause pce->tmpMap to resize, hence previous results
3708              from VG_(indexXA) are invalid. */
3709           ent = (TempMapEnt*)VG_(indexXA)( pce->qmpMap, (Word)orig );
3710           tl_assert(ent->kind == NonShad);
3711           tl_assert(ent->shadow == IRTemp_INVALID);
3712           ent->shadow = shadow;
3713        }
3714        return ent->shadow;
3715     }
3716     
3717     /* Allocate a new shadow for the given original tmp.  This means any
3718        previous shadow is abandoned.  This is needed because it is
3719        necessary to give a new value to a shadow once it has been tested
3720        for undefinedness, but unfortunately IR's SSA property disallows
3721        this.  Instead we must abandon the old shadow, allocate a new one
3722        and use that instead.
3723     
3724        This is the same as findShadowTmp, except we don't bother to see
3725        if a shadow temp already existed -- we simply allocate a new one
3726        regardless. */
3727     static IRTemp newShadowTmp ( PCEnv* pce, IRTemp orig )
3728     {
3729        TempMapEnt* ent;
3730        /* VG_(indexXA) range-checks 'orig', hence no need to check
3731           here. */
3732        ent = (TempMapEnt*)VG_(indexXA)( pce->qmpMap, (Word)orig );
3733        tl_assert(ent->kind == NonShad);
3734        if (1) {
3735           IRTemp shadow = newTemp( pce, pce->gWordTy, Shad );
3736           /* newTemp may cause pce->tmpMap to resize, hence previous results
3737              from VG_(indexXA) are invalid. */
3738           ent = (TempMapEnt*)VG_(indexXA)( pce->qmpMap, (Word)orig );
3739           tl_assert(ent->kind == NonShad);
3740           ent->shadow = shadow;
3741           return shadow;
3742        }
3743        /* NOTREACHED */
3744        tl_assert(0);
3745     }
3746     
3747     
3748     /*------------------------------------------------------------*/
3749     /*--- IRAtoms -- a subset of IRExprs                       ---*/
3750     /*------------------------------------------------------------*/
3751     
3752     /* An atom is either an IRExpr_Const or an IRExpr_Tmp, as defined by
3753        isIRAtom() in libvex_ir.h.  Because this instrumenter expects flat
3754        input, most of this code deals in atoms.  Usefully, a value atom
3755        always has a V-value which is also an atom: constants are shadowed
3756        by constants, and temps are shadowed by the corresponding shadow
3757        temporary. */
3758     
3759     typedef  IRExpr  IRAtom;
3760     
3761     //zz /* (used for sanity checks only): is this an atom which looks
3762     //zz    like it's from original code? */
3763     //zz static Bool isOriginalAtom ( PCEnv* pce, IRAtom* a1 )
3764     //zz {
3765     //zz    if (a1->tag == Iex_Const)
3766     //zz       return True;
3767     //zz    if (a1->tag == Iex_RdTmp && a1->Iex.RdTmp.tmp < pce->n_originalTmps)
3768     //zz       return True;
3769     //zz    return False;
3770     //zz }
3771     //zz 
3772     //zz /* (used for sanity checks only): is this an atom which looks
3773     //zz    like it's from shadow code? */
3774     //zz static Bool isShadowAtom ( PCEnv* pce, IRAtom* a1 )
3775     //zz {
3776     //zz    if (a1->tag == Iex_Const)
3777     //zz       return True;
3778     //zz    if (a1->tag == Iex_RdTmp && a1->Iex.RdTmp.tmp >= pce->n_originalTmps)
3779     //zz       return True;
3780     //zz    return False;
3781     //zz }
3782     //zz 
3783     //zz /* (used for sanity checks only): check that both args are atoms and
3784     //zz    are identically-kinded. */
3785     //zz static Bool sameKindedAtoms ( IRAtom* a1, IRAtom* a2 )
3786     //zz {
3787     //zz    if (a1->tag == Iex_RdTmp && a2->tag == Iex_RdTmp)
3788     //zz       return True;
3789     //zz    if (a1->tag == Iex_Const && a2->tag == Iex_Const)
3790     //zz       return True;
3791     //zz    return False;
3792     //zz }
3793     
3794     
3795     /*------------------------------------------------------------*/
3796     /*--- Constructing IR fragments                            ---*/
3797     /*------------------------------------------------------------*/
3798     
3799     /* add stmt to a bb */
3800     static inline void stmt ( HChar cat, PCEnv* pce, IRStmt* st ) {
3801        if (pce->trace) {
3802           VG_(printf)("  %c: ", cat);
3803           ppIRStmt(st);
3804           VG_(printf)("\n");
3805        }
3806        addStmtToIRSB(pce->sb, st);
3807     }
3808     
3809     /* assign value to tmp */
3810     static inline
3811     void assign ( HChar cat, PCEnv* pce, IRTemp tmp, IRExpr* expr ) {
3812        stmt(cat, pce, IRStmt_WrTmp(tmp,expr));
3813     }
3814     
3815     /* build various kinds of expressions */
3816     #define binop(_op, _arg1, _arg2) IRExpr_Binop((_op),(_arg1),(_arg2))
3817     #define unop(_op, _arg)          IRExpr_Unop((_op),(_arg))
3818     #define mkU8(_n)                 IRExpr_Const(IRConst_U8(_n))
3819     #define mkU16(_n)                IRExpr_Const(IRConst_U16(_n))
3820     #define mkU32(_n)                IRExpr_Const(IRConst_U32(_n))
3821     #define mkU64(_n)                IRExpr_Const(IRConst_U64(_n))
3822     #define mkV128(_n)               IRExpr_Const(IRConst_V128(_n))
3823     #define mkexpr(_tmp)             IRExpr_RdTmp((_tmp))
3824     
3825     /* Bind the given expression to a new temporary, and return the
3826        temporary.  This effectively converts an arbitrary expression into
3827        an atom.
3828     
3829        'ty' is the type of 'e' and hence the type that the new temporary
3830        needs to be.  But passing it is redundant, since we can deduce the
3831        type merely by inspecting 'e'.  So at least that fact to assert
3832        that the two types agree. */
3833     static IRAtom* assignNew ( HChar cat, PCEnv* pce, IRType ty, IRExpr* e ) {
3834        IRTemp t;
3835        IRType tyE = typeOfIRExpr(pce->sb->tyenv, e);
3836        tl_assert(tyE == ty); /* so 'ty' is redundant (!) */
3837        t = newTemp(pce, ty, Shad);
3838        assign(cat, pce, t, e);
3839        return mkexpr(t);
3840     }
3841     
3842     
3843     
3844     //-----------------------------------------------------------------------
3845     // Approach taken for range-checking for NONPTR/UNKNOWN-ness as follows.
3846     //
3847     // Range check (NONPTR/seg): 
3848     // - after modifying a word-sized value in/into a TempReg:
3849     //    - {ADD, SUB, ADC, SBB, AND, OR, XOR, LEA, LEA2, NEG, NOT}L
3850     //    - BSWAP
3851     // 
3852     // Range check (NONPTR/UNKNOWN):
3853     // - when introducing a new word-sized value into a TempReg:
3854     //    - MOVL l, t2
3855     //
3856     // - when copying a word-sized value which lacks a corresponding segment
3857     //   into a TempReg:
3858     //    - straddled LDL
3859     //
3860     // - when a sub-word of a word (or two) is updated:
3861     //    - SHROTL
3862     //    - {ADD, SUB, ADC, SBB, AND, OR, XOR, SHROT, NEG, NOT}[WB]
3863     //    - PUT[WB]
3864     //    - straddled   STL (2 range checks)
3865     //    - straddled   STW (2 range checks)
3866     //    - unstraddled STW
3867     //    - STB
3868     //    
3869     // Just copy:
3870     // - when copying word-sized values:
3871     //    - MOVL t1, t2 (--optimise=no only)
3872     //    - CMOV
3873     //    - GETL, PUTL
3874     //    - unstraddled LDL, unstraddled STL
3875     //
3876     // - when barely changing
3877     //    - INC[LWB]/DEC[LWB]
3878     // 
3879     // Set to NONPTR:
3880     // - after copying a sub-word value into a TempReg:
3881     //    - MOV[WB] l, t2
3882     //    - GET[WB]
3883     //    - unstraddled LDW
3884     //    - straddled   LDW
3885     //    - LDB
3886     //    - POP[WB]
3887     //
3888     // - after copying an obvious non-ptr into a TempReg:
3889     //    - GETF
3890     //    - CC2VAL
3891     //    - POPL
3892     //
3893     // - after copying an obvious non-ptr into a memory word:
3894     //    - FPU_W
3895     // 
3896     // Do nothing:
3897     // - LOCK, INCEIP
3898     // - WIDEN[WB]
3899     // - JMP, JIFZ
3900     // - CALLM_[SE], PUSHL, CALLM, CLEAR
3901     // - FPU, FPU_R (and similar MMX/SSE ones)
3902     //
3903     
3904     
3905     
3906     
3907     /* Call h_fn (name h_nm) with the given arg, and return a new IRTemp
3908        holding the result.  The arg must be a word-typed atom.  Callee
3909        must be a VG_REGPARM(1) function. */
3910     __attribute__((noinline))
3911     static IRTemp gen_dirty_W_W ( PCEnv* pce, void* h_fn, HChar* h_nm, 
3912                                   IRExpr* a1 )
3913     {
3914        IRTemp   res;
3915        IRDirty* di;
3916        tl_assert(isIRAtom(a1));
3917        tl_assert(typeOfIRExpr(pce->sb->tyenv, a1) == pce->gWordTy);
3918        res = newTemp(pce, pce->gWordTy, Shad);
3919        di = unsafeIRDirty_1_N( res, 1/*regparms*/,
3920                                h_nm, VG_(fnptr_to_fnentry)( h_fn ),
3921                                mkIRExprVec_1( a1 ) );
3922        stmt( 'I', pce, IRStmt_Dirty(di) );
3923        return res;
3924     }
3925     
3926     /* Two-arg version of gen_dirty_W_W.  Callee must be a VG_REGPARM(2)
3927        function.*/
3928     static IRTemp gen_dirty_W_WW ( PCEnv* pce, void* h_fn, HChar* h_nm, 
3929                                    IRExpr* a1, IRExpr* a2 )
3930     {
3931        IRTemp   res;
3932        IRDirty* di;
3933        tl_assert(isIRAtom(a1));
3934        tl_assert(isIRAtom(a2));
3935        tl_assert(typeOfIRExpr(pce->sb->tyenv, a1) == pce->gWordTy);
3936        tl_assert(typeOfIRExpr(pce->sb->tyenv, a2) == pce->gWordTy);
3937        res = newTemp(pce, pce->gWordTy, Shad);
3938        di = unsafeIRDirty_1_N( res, 2/*regparms*/,
3939                                h_nm, VG_(fnptr_to_fnentry)( h_fn ),
3940                                mkIRExprVec_2( a1, a2 ) );
3941        stmt( 'I', pce, IRStmt_Dirty(di) );
3942        return res;
3943     }
3944     
3945     /* Three-arg version of gen_dirty_W_W.  Callee must be a VG_REGPARM(3)
3946        function.*/
3947     static IRTemp gen_dirty_W_WWW ( PCEnv* pce, void* h_fn, HChar* h_nm, 
3948                                     IRExpr* a1, IRExpr* a2, IRExpr* a3 )
3949     {
3950        IRTemp   res;
3951        IRDirty* di;
3952        tl_assert(isIRAtom(a1));
3953        tl_assert(isIRAtom(a2));
3954        tl_assert(isIRAtom(a3));
3955        tl_assert(typeOfIRExpr(pce->sb->tyenv, a1) == pce->gWordTy);
3956        tl_assert(typeOfIRExpr(pce->sb->tyenv, a2) == pce->gWordTy);
3957        tl_assert(typeOfIRExpr(pce->sb->tyenv, a3) == pce->gWordTy);
3958        res = newTemp(pce, pce->gWordTy, Shad);
3959        di = unsafeIRDirty_1_N( res, 3/*regparms*/,
3960                                h_nm, VG_(fnptr_to_fnentry)( h_fn ),
3961                                mkIRExprVec_3( a1, a2, a3 ) );
3962        stmt( 'I', pce, IRStmt_Dirty(di) );
3963        return res;
3964     }
3965     
3966     /* Four-arg version of gen_dirty_W_W.  Callee must be a VG_REGPARM(3)
3967        function.*/
3968     static IRTemp gen_dirty_W_WWWW ( PCEnv* pce, void* h_fn, HChar* h_nm, 
3969                                      IRExpr* a1, IRExpr* a2,
3970                                      IRExpr* a3, IRExpr* a4 )
3971     {
3972        IRTemp   res;
3973        IRDirty* di;
3974        tl_assert(isIRAtom(a1));
3975        tl_assert(isIRAtom(a2));
3976        tl_assert(isIRAtom(a3));
3977        tl_assert(isIRAtom(a4));
3978        tl_assert(typeOfIRExpr(pce->sb->tyenv, a1) == pce->gWordTy);
3979        tl_assert(typeOfIRExpr(pce->sb->tyenv, a2) == pce->gWordTy);
3980        tl_assert(typeOfIRExpr(pce->sb->tyenv, a3) == pce->gWordTy);
3981        tl_assert(typeOfIRExpr(pce->sb->tyenv, a4) == pce->gWordTy);
3982        res = newTemp(pce, pce->gWordTy, Shad);
3983        di = unsafeIRDirty_1_N( res, 3/*regparms*/,
3984                                h_nm, VG_(fnptr_to_fnentry)( h_fn ),
3985                                mkIRExprVec_4( a1, a2, a3, a4 ) );
3986        stmt( 'I', pce, IRStmt_Dirty(di) );
3987        return res;
3988     }
3989     
3990     /* Version of gen_dirty_W_WW with no return value.  Callee must be a
3991        VG_REGPARM(2) function.  If guard is non-NULL then it is used to
3992        conditionalise the call. */
3993     static void gen_dirty_v_WW ( PCEnv* pce, IRExpr* guard,
3994                                  void* h_fn, HChar* h_nm, 
3995                                  IRExpr* a1, IRExpr* a2 )
3996     {
3997        IRDirty* di;
3998        tl_assert(isIRAtom(a1));
3999        tl_assert(isIRAtom(a2));
4000        tl_assert(typeOfIRExpr(pce->sb->tyenv, a1) == pce->gWordTy);
4001        tl_assert(typeOfIRExpr(pce->sb->tyenv, a2) == pce->gWordTy);
4002        di = unsafeIRDirty_0_N( 2/*regparms*/,
4003                                h_nm, VG_(fnptr_to_fnentry)( h_fn ),
4004                                mkIRExprVec_2( a1, a2 ) );
4005        if (guard)
4006           di->guard = guard;
4007        stmt( 'I', pce, IRStmt_Dirty(di) );
4008     }

4013                                   IRExpr* a1, IRExpr* a2, IRExpr* a3 )

4020        tl_assert(typeOfIRExpr(pce->sb->tyenv, a2) == pce->gWordTy);

4051     static void gen_dirty_v_6W ( PCEnv* pce, void* h_fn, HChar* h_nm,
